div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE The Counteſs of SALISBURY.
div.p: THE Attention with which you have protected the Britiſh Stage, claims the Gratitude of every Dramatic Writer: I therefore take the Liberty of dedicating this Comedy to your Ladyſhip, and humbly entreat your Forgiveneſs for not previouſly ſoliciting your Permiſſion.

closer.salute: I have the Honour to be, MY LADY,
closer.signed: With the greateſt Reſpect, Your Ladyſhip's moſt obedient And moſt humble Servant, LEONARD MAC NALLY.

div.head: On ſeeing Miſs YOUNGE in the Character of Lady FLIPPANT SAVAGE.
div.l: THE two ſcenic Muſes had long kept a diſtance,
And ſcorn'd of each other to borrow aſſiſtance;
THALIA was pert, and MELPOMENE proud,
And though of admirers they both had a croud;
Not two rival beauties on earth could be ſeen
More tortur'd with jealouſy, envy and ſpleen:
Till JOVE, to whom all the celeſtials ſubmit,
In matters of WEIGHT, or in matters of WIT,
Interpos'd his command, ſaying, henceforth agree,
United in friendſhip as Siſters ſhould be;
And grant, as a pledge that your union's ſincere,
Your mutual pow'rs to ſome favourite fair;
If one can be found amongſt mortals below
Deſerving the attributes you can beſtow.
The Siſters obey'd; but unfix'd was their choice,
Till MINERVA appearing with ſoul-moving voice:
While in ſcales of ſuſpenſe both their fancies were hung,
Appeal'd to their ſenſes, and pointed to YOUNGE.
To YOUNGE, where the ſmile-ſtealing comic we find,
With the ſoft, the ſublime, and the graceful combin'd.
To YOUNGE who can each diff'rent paſſion impart,
Who pleaſes the judgement, but conquers the heart,
And guided by NATURE, is followed by ART.

sp.l: IN Shakeſpeare's days we only play'd the fool,
And men of faſhion gave—not took—the rule;
Then Lords were grave, and ladies graver ſtill,
And only we, and clowns had wit at will;
His mind rejected former claſſic lore,
And drew from Nature's never-ending ſtore.
But authors now—we often prove the fact,
Muſt faſhion court, to teach us how to act.
Expoſe the follies which our ſtatutes ſpare,
And unprotected Virtue make their care.
All nature now is cuſtom;—cuſtom, law;
And here we bring—not what we think,—but ſaw.
Tis hard to vary your dramatic mirth,
When every folly gives it likeneſs birth.
Which though, in life, your laugh they may command,
Will rather pall, than pleaſe, at ſecond hand.
'Tis harder ſtill to ſuit the general mind,
And all our audience in our int'reſt bind.
Honeſt John Bull, vex'd with the cares of life,
With heavy taxes and a ſcolding wife,
Wiſhes ſome hours in hearing us to waſte,
And galloping dreary Dun is quite his taſte.—
Sir Foppling too, his brains with claret addle,
Pronounces Comedy to be a Twaddle!
His Lordſhip by the privilege of folly,
Is neither muſical nor melancholy;
Thinks every honeſt bard a queer old Put,—
"Damme! there's nothing in a play like ſmut!
The politician's all-commanding pate,
Would have us dramatize th' affairs of ſtate:
Make whigs and tories fight, here face to face,
And teach the patriots, Unity of Place.—
Some cry for ſentiment, and ſome for wit,
And yet our claim to either won't admit.—
The Critic Bench!Looking into the Pit. for which there's no appeal,
Since for the town they judge, and act, and feel.
Did you but know what pangs an author ſhares,
How throbs his heart with anxious doubts and cares!
Let paſt indulgence your attention keep:
Though we be dull—Juſtice ſhould never ſleep.
And if to-night no merit we can claim,
The want of power, not will, deſerves the blame!

div.head: ACT I.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Muſ.
sp.p: AND do you really prefer London to Bath, Mrs. Grace?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Why, I do; in London there's ſuch a noiſe—ſuch rattling of carts, waggons, coaches, chariots and vis-a-vis; then at night its ſo charming to ſee the flambeaux flying about from houſe to houſe, like blazing ſtars!—But what have you got there for my lady, Mrs. Muſlin?

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: A few cards of laces.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Foreign, I hope—we hate every thing Engliſh, and wear nothing but foreign manufactures. (Bell rings) My lady's bell.—Any new company come down?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Muſ.
sp.p: Have heard of none, except the wife and daughter of big Mr. Minikin, the great pinmaker from Threadneedle-ſtreet. (Bell rings.)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Coming, my lady (goes to a door in the back ſcene.) It is only Mrs. Muſlin, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: within. I'll be with her immediately.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Let me have a few words with you before you go—Sir Buzzard and my lady had ſuch tifting yeſterday, you never heard the like—They hate each other moſt affectionately, that is the truth of it—

div.stage: Enter Lady FLIPPANT SAVAGE through a door in the back ſcene.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: So Muſlin, (ſits) Heigh ho! I'm all langour and laſſitude!—Never knew Bath ſo dull—Scarce any perſon of faſhion—Nobody one knows—This patch has a pretty effect—And you may go, Grace; and do you hear, Grace, let Miſs Conſtance know I ſhall be ready to go out in half an hour.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Yes, my lady. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Muſlin, take a chair;—this is certainly Engliſh rouge, a vulgar natural red.—Did you ſee my brute as you came in, Muſlin?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Muſ.
sp.p: Saw two of them, dear pretty animals, in the hall, my lady; the little French dog was playing with the Spaniſh monkey.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Muſlin, are you mad!—my dog and monkey brutes! ſweet creatures! I was enquiring after the brute my huſband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Muſ.
sp.p: I aſk your ladyſhip's pardon; I ſaw Sir Buzzard with Colonel Staff, and Mr. Cheaterly in the great parlour.—But I have ſomething to mention to your ladyſhip—here are the laces— (opening the box) but it is not about the laces I want to ſpeak—but—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: But what?—Heigh ho! hand me the Olympian dew—Muſlin, I ſaw a charming fellow at the play laſt night, and he ſaw me—Lady Holden certainly pencils her eye-brows—But the charming fellow, he took up my whole attention from the performance—I flatter myſelf I engaged his—his eyes were never off me—was dreſſed in a new Pariſian frock.—Hand me the volatile ſalts, Muſlin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Muſ.
sp.p: My lodger, I proteſt!—pick'd the pinion of a chicken at my humble table, laſt night, and never ceaſed talking of your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Hand me the roſe water—he ſpoke of me, you ſay?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Muſ.
sp.p: Heav'ns, ſaid he, what an air!—what grace! then run on in praiſe of your ladyſhip's perſon and beauty; but when he heard your ladyſhip was married, poor youth, how piteouſly he ſigh'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Good natured charitable ſoul!—but his name—who is he?—what is he? whence came he?—and who are his relations, Muſlin?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Muſ.
sp.p: Cannot anſwer one of your ladyſhip's queſtions, except that his name is Welford; he came to my houſe yeſterday, and talks of leaving Bath to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Mr. Cheaterly requeſts permiſſion to wait upon your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p:
Shew him up.
Exit. Grace. Come to demand his winnings;—loſt two hundred laſt night, could think of no card but the knave of hearts I ſaw at the Theatre.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Muſ.
sp.p: The knave—the king of hearts your ladyſhip means; and let me tell you a trump—never ſaw finer eyes; then he has the leg of a ſoldier, and the hand of a lady—but is he to have the honor of—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Muſ.
sp.p: He ſays he has ſomething of a ſerious nature to communicate to your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Perhaps letters from ſome of my friends in Paris.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Saw a large bundle of letters on his table.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Then, Muſlin, I leave his introduction to you—ſhall be at home all the morning.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip's moſt obedient—I leave the laces. (going) Never ſaw a handſomer gentleman. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: What a giddy creature am I? but a body muſt kill time—then the fellow is ſo elegant, (riſes) and Sir Buzzard ſo peeviſh!—the fatigue and apprehenſion which body and mind ſuffer after an unluckly run, are inſupportable; my nerves are quite out of tune, but Muſlin has in ſome degree elevated my ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I condole with your ladyſhip on your hard run laſt night; the aces conſpired againſt you;—Renounce brag, the cunning of the game lies, not in—judgment of mind, but in command of muſcles.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: To which I impute your uninterrupted ſeries of good luck.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I am unfit for brag;—the warmth of my heart, particularly in your ladyſhip's preſence, (bows low.) keeps my features in continual rebellion,—but no perſon with a flexible countenance ſhould touch brag, the impenetrable looks of lady Frigid Midnight, have eſtabliſhed her an adept at the game.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: And her nimble fingers give her command of the cards; but ſhe loſt temper when I got the black knaves; it was when you ſtood on my right, and lord Lackacre on my left hand.—"I have got the black knaves," ſaid I, "Lady Frigid"—"I ſee you have," ſaid ſhe, pointing to you and my lord,—then, as ſhe puckered up her mouth in an affected ſmile, down fell a few flakes of paint, and her ſkin appeared under the fractures, like old brick work peeping through the new invented compoſition.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Her countenance was once tolerable, but a long run of ill luck, has ſtamp'd that irriſible diſcordancy, of hill and dale, which marks her viſage, and prevents the ſmiles of fortune, joy, or good humour, from unbending her to a laugh, or the ſmalleſt ſemblage of the amiable. (Hums a tune.) There is a ſmall matter between us, for which I have a very preſſing occaſion.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Aſide.) I expected this! Ha! ha! ha! I cannot but laugh at your deſcription of Lady Frigid.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: For heav'n's ſake ſay no more of her;—but, let me have the money. (bows.)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: The money! Pſha! You muſt have patience.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Patience for a debt of honour!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I have bills to pay—my mercer, milliner, and mantua-maker, are to be with me to-morrow, and people of that claſs, you know, are rude and importunate.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe I point out a mode of diſcharging this debt of honour without diminiſhing your ladyſhip's purſe—what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: If you have any thing to propoſe I can honourably receive, ſpeak out.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip is not uſually ſlow of apprehenſion;—it is true, I have not made an open declaration of my paſſion.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: But my eyes, my looks, have ſpoke the workings of my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Goes from him confuſed) This I never ſuſpected. (Aſide)

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: May I hope for your aſſiſtance towards my happineſs; I have long loved, doated, and deſpaired.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Long loved and doated! I'm not ſurprized at that. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Sir Buzzard knows of, and approves my paſſion.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: Sir Buzzard approves it!

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: He does,—and I cannot live—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Hold, Sir! (Aſide.) I'm aſtoniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I cannot live without her.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Without her! without whom?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Who but Conſtance!—divine Conſtance!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Though I deſpiſe the fellow!—I—I—but why ſhould I be ruffled?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: She thought I was making love to herſelf. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And wou'd you have me acceſſary to the ruin of a young creature?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: There is no ruin intended;—I have open'd my mind to the lady,—Sir Buzzard is my friend, and I only ſolicit your intereſt; I would marry Conſtance.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: No ruin intended! could a greater curſe befal a young creature than to marry you!—who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Who am I, madam! a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I don't mean to aſperſe your birth, Sir; but is not your ruling paſſion play; your principal dependance cards and dice; your moſt intimate connections jockies, grooms, gamecocks, and race-horſes? I am ſurprized you could look up to her.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: My fortune and family entitle me to look up to any woman.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Then it muſt be merely to look up; you are, no doubt, one of Fortune's favourites, and her favours follow you;—you have large eſtates in expectancy, and conſiderable rents in Bath, Wells, Scarborough, Southampton and Margate; nay, more, you have as many agents as the firſt landed gentleman in the country.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I don't underſtand this treatment.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p:
Your connexions, manners and converſation
would be perfectly agreeable to Conſtance's turn of mind;—her reſpect for religion, her morality, philoſophy, and knowledge of the belles lettres, would exactly coincide with your ſtudies in the arts and ſciences of play.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Arts and ſciences of play—

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: I inſinuate nothing injurious to your profeſſion; the reſpect which profeſſors of play receive in preference to all other profeſſors proves it a profeſſion the moſt l • beral, as well as moſt profitable. (ironically.)

sp.speaker: Cheat.
Lady Flip.
sp.p: You ſay the debt of honour ſhall be cancelled. Are you aware that Conſtance has beſtowed her favours on young De Courcy, of York.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Yes; and that his paſſion for play was cooled at the laſt York races, which obliged him to take a trip to France for the recovery of his finances.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And his loſſes ſhe imputes to a conſpiracy between you and thoſe friends of yours, who were the oſtenſible winners, and to whom you introduced him;—I ſear you have no chance.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Chance!—leave me to that;—I have often won with the odds againſt me; then ſhe is a beggar, but my paſſion is diſintereſted.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p:
And pray now, how much of the
uncle's debt of honour is to be paid by this parental kindneſs to the niece?—I ſee into the ſcheme,—and here comes the unfortunate ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I underſtand your ladyſhip deſired to ſpeak with me.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p:
To inform you, my dear, of ſome engagements, but particular buſineſs calls me away for a few minutes, ſo I leave you to entertain Mr. Cheaterly.
Exit Lady Flippant.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Her modeſt bluſh puts even my impudence out of countenance!—your ſolicitude, madam, to avoid me, ſo ſtrongly indicates apathy to my addreſſes, I almoſt dread the poſſibility of convincing you I am ſincere;—do not turn from me in ſcorn; I may have ſome claim upon your gratitude, though no intereſt in your heart.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Gratitude! Oh! Your abſence, Sir, I muſt inſiſt on; I will not, in future, be perſecuted by your preſumption!

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I acknowledge my weakneſs in purſuing the impulſe of my paſſion; reaſon checks me, but ſuch is the imperious violence of my affection, that even your ſcorn increaſes my deſires, by making you lovely in the midſt of anger, and the bleſſing I ſigh for, appears ſtill more valuable, more worthy purſuit, from the diſtant proſpect you give me of the poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Proſpect, Sir!

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Yes, madam, proſpect.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You will be pleaſed, Sir, to withdraw— walks diſconcerted. you are inſolent.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Inſolent! a hard word, madam, to a man who prefers you to every other woman,—I may be bold, madam, but—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I repeat it, you are inſolent.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I am calm, madam; I know the impediment to my happineſs, young lady, and have ſpirit to remove it.—Inſolent! ha; you prefer a clandeſtine correſpondence with a bankrupt in fame and fortune, to the generous addreſſes of a man, honoured with your uncle's approbation, and independent of the world.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: The engagements of my heart—but I will not weep— (wiping her eyes) —Sir—you have, with a baſe and mean cowardice, dared to traduce a generous, unſuſpecting youth, whoſe fortune you have aſſiſted to ruin, but whoſe honour you can never taint;—a youth who, if preſent, you would not dare to look on withouttrembling. (going.)

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Enquire of that gentleman, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: What a life I lead! my mind kept in a continual fever, you and your aunt are a perpetual ague to me;—her hot fits of levity, and your cool fits of prudery, operate alternately, and I am tortured by you from morning till night.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
I muſt tell you, Sir, that ſince your houſe cannot afford me protection, I ſhall leave it; and, though deſtitute of fortune, I know where to apply for an aſylum.
Ex. Conſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
"I know where to apply for an aſylum!"—She cannot have a knowledge of our ſecret, or I would ſuppoſe ſhe meant the Chancery;
a man muſt now pay as much attention to his ward, as if ſhe was his child.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: True, and what adds to the grievance, if a young fellow marries an heireſs, he is obliged to ſettle her fortune on herſelf, though, perhaps, her perſon was a ſecondary object,—I ſhall never ſucceed here, Sir Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Piſh, why not ſucceed; a hundred to one but all ſhe has ſaid is pretence,—you know nothing of women's ſubtilty; they ſmile, they frown, they laugh, they weep, they move but to deceive us, and lay a ſnare in every article of their dreſs.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: De Courcy is the object of her choice.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Why afraid of De Courcy? his friends at York races plucked the poor devil of a pigeon ſo bare, they ſcarcely left him feathers to fly into France.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I was preſent;—may I depend on your aſſiſtance?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Is not our bargain concluded?—on the day of your marriage with my niece, you return me my mortgages, the bill of ſale upon my horſes, and an acquittance of all demands.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Depend upon it—I have pledg'd my honour;—aſſiſt me, and I will purſue my game, though ſhe keeps me at bay every ſtep.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Cheaterly, I muſt look about me; I came down here for the recovery of my health, and am ſuffering under a precipitate conſumption of my purſe. Do you think the young clergyman plays fair?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: You mean parſon Spruce; could you ſuſpect a divine?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
Why, yes; I do ſuſpect your divines
in their own hair, and boots, many of them I believe have thrown off morality with their wigs, and kicked away religion with their ſhoes.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: But Dr. Spruce has three hundred a year in the church—he won a cool fifty from me.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: A fifty! I loſt more to him than would purchaſe four years of his income.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Do you want caſh? I can lend you a hundred; here (gives him a note) with friends money ſhould be a common commodity.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Why I loſt this note to Parſon Spruce laſt night—he gave me a fifty and took it.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Aye, Oh, I had it from him, he gave it to me for a bill on London.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Here comes Colonel Staff and old Ordeal yoked together, very naturally, as two aſſes ſhould be;—I deſpiſe them both: the Colonel never ſerved abroad, yet he prates as bold as if he had experienced half a dozen foreign campaigns.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: And is poor and proud.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, but hopes to mend his fortune by marrying my ſiſter; I wiſh him ſucceſs, that they may mutually torment each other.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Mark Ordeal, he is not a leſs extraordinary character than the Colonel, the fellow was a foundling, and never knew his parents, but having acquired a fortune by trade, impudently inſults his betters, by preaching what he calls generoſity.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
O, confound his generoſity, he is always ſetting a bad example with his charities,
relieving widows, providing for orphans, and portioning off young maidens; though ignorant as a Hottentot, he has got himſelf rank'd among the literati, and ſets up for a philoſopher—the fellow has come into life through as many ſhapes as an Orkney Barnacle, he was firſt a block, then a worm, and is now a gooſe.

div.stage: Enter Colonel STAFF, and Mr. ORDEAL.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I have been accuſing Ordeal of avarice, and he denies the charge.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I do, avarice, though too often an attendant on age, is a vice foreign to my nature; no man can accuſe me of accumulating money by unjuſt means, or of hoarding it when in my poſſeſſion; whereas avarice is a dropſy of the mind—a diſeaſe that irritates and increaſes by the means uſed to aſſuage its thirſt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Have you not refuſed to lend me a mere trifle, and being rich, is not that a proof of avarice.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Hear me;—I conſider myſelf an agent, bound to anſwer for the diſtribution of that wealth with which heaven has bleſs'd my induſtry—the charge of avarice is more applicable to the ſpendthrift than the prudent, the ſpendthrift graſps at every man's property; yet no man is accounted avaricious who conforms to the cuſtom of diſſipation; though the ſpendthrift raiſes his rents, and ſtarves his tenantry—borrows money and ruins his friend, or runs in debt, and makes bankrupts of his tradeſmen, if he drives a carriage—keeps a train of ſervants, plays, drinks, and plunges into vice, the world will call him a damn'd generous fellow—I ſpeak my mind—that's my way.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Well, Colonel, how goes on your affair with my fantaſtical ſiſter? She is a jilt, Colonel.—I hate a jilt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: She will ſoon ſurrender, I have got poſſeſſion of the counterſcarp▪ and ſhall ſhortly ſet up the ſtandard of matrimony upon the crown of the—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Horn work—Eh?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: The widow has a conſiderable ſhare of the toujours gai in her compoſition.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Too much to promiſe conſtancy; but then you old bachelors have ſuch winning ways—but Colonel, keep a centinel on my ſiſter—time and poſſeſſion are two dangerous pioneers; the firſt moulders the cement by degrees; and the other ſaps the foundation.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Then the widow is ſo frank, degagé and good natured, ſhe may grant favors from charity and ſenſibility, which other women would refuſe from principle, or the prejudice of education.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: What Mr. Cheaterly has advanced, contains profound gravity of judgment; but my Clary ſhall have no modern education, I have engaged a maſter to teach her the Claſſics, to manure the ſoil by cultivating the ſeeds of virtue;—yes, I will have Clary cultivated; for ſhe is innocence itſelf: free from the bias of example, ſhe is guided only by the impulſe of pure nature.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: A young lady could not have a more dangerous preceptor, the impulſe of pure nature will produce every evil that can ariſe from the politeſt education.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
I am convinc'd ſhe is delicate as the ermine,
which would die to preſerve the ſnowy whiteneſs of its fur.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well ſaid, my old friend, amorous as May, though grey as December.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Grey! Nay, let me tell you, Colonel; though ſnow has fallen upon the mountain, there is ſunſhine in the valley—Clara is an Aurora Borealis, a blaze in the regions of frigidity.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Ordeal, ſeriouſly, now, are you going to marry this ward of your's for love?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Seriouſly, I love the girl as I love my life; but if I did not, having no relations nor friends to whom I owe any obligation, I am determined to make her my heir.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: And no doubt ſhe will bring you an heir in return, and then bury you.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Bury me!—Granted: when I ſleep peaceable under the green turf, let her marry ſome honeſt young fellow, and their children ſhall bear my name.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: A good way this to raiſe a family without trouble.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Family, I underſtand your ſneer, I was a foundling it is true, and cannot boaſt anceſtry; yet I have a heart ſuſceptible of the tender feelings and ſweet ſolicitudes of humanity. Though I cannot claim relations of particular deſcriptions, I know Adam and Eve were our primitive parents, therefore, conſider the world one common family, and hold myſelf bound to all mankind by ties of fraternal love.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: And your family kindneſs is not confined to your brothers, but extends to your ſiſters too.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
Clara's father was my friend, we ſerv'd our apprenticeſhip together, ſet up in the ſame
branch of trade, he failed, and died poor, but I proſpered—he was a worthy ſoul, and I never ſpeak of him without tears. (weeps.)

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ah! very good, Sir Buzzard; becauſe the father was his juvenile friend he would marry the daughter in his old age.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: A pretty excuſe for a vicious appetite.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hear, hear!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Clara's father, when on his death-bed, bequeathed her to me as a legacy, it was a bequeſt of confidence, and I eſteem it more than if it had been a million: he bequeathed her to me an infant without a mother, without relations, without friends, without fortune.—Now, though rich in the liberal gifts of nature, who hath endowed her with an exuberant hand, yet being poor in worldly ſubſtance, ſhe hath but few attractions for a huſband; the knight errants of theſe days are Argonauts—this is the golden age and every thing is bought and ſold.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Spoke in the true ſpirit of commerce, my old merchant.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Sir Knight, the ſpirit of commerce is the beſt ſpirit in the nation; we merchants live by barter and ſale it is true, but take this with you, ſir, probity is our principle, and our character nice as a lady's.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
Here comes my moiety of mortality—here comes the origin of two thirds of my complaints, with my widow'd ſiſter, the Colonel's tormentor that is to be—ſee, they ſmile at ſome miſchief in embryo—Ah, candied ginger, ſugar on the outſide, fire within, ſweet on the palate, biting on the tongue. Ordeal keep a
ſtrict eye upon pure nature, the aloe is moſt bitter when green▪ (going.)

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Nay, ſtay, Sir Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Stay, and my wife coming! excuſe me, I avoid her as I would an epidemic complaint. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lady FLIPPANT SAVAGE and Widow VOLATILE.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Are you here, Colonel? I follow you as the little bird does the cuckoo—Mr. Ordeal, your moſt obedient, how is pretty Clara, and when are we to call her Mrs. Ordeal.—You rear her quite a domeſtic animal, ſhe is never ſeen abroad.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Nor at home, ſiſter, not even at the windows.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: He fears the ſun would ſpoil her complexion.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: She hath indeed a lovely complexion, glowing and bright as the Tyrian dye, not a modern local bluſh, that hides ſhame inſtead of diſcovering it; but ruddy health moving in varied tints—the lily and the roſe vying for pre-eminence on her cheek!—O ſhe is pure nature!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But when introduced to life thoſe roſes will blow, thoſe lilies will fade.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: She ſhall never get into any life, but where they may blow and fade naturally—her real face ſhall never be concealed under a counterfeit; ſome ladies coin complexions, and ſhould be puniſhed for high treaſon in defacing beauty.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Bravo, old Ordeal! bravo!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
I reprobate impoſition of charms! a reverend biſhop declared to me he was married
two years before he ſaw his wife's face, and that was by accident.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed a gentleman of your age can be ſo ſcandalous, ſo malicious, but it is the nature of waſps to retain their buz after they have loſt their ſting.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Our gaiety provokes their ſpleen; theſe ancient gentlemen rail at women for ſpeaking ſcandal, yet reſort in groupes to every place of public entertainment, ogl'ng with their teleſcope eyes to diſcover blemiſhes on beautiful objects—now here's a piece of antiquity!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I have not pretended to juvenality ſince the crow's feet appeared near my eyes; nay, don't bite your lips, widow, lines will appear in the ſkin after thirty, and are the harbingers to wrinkles.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The chocolate is ready, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Siſter, let us in—Mr. Cheaterly—

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I attend your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Can I pay my reſpects to Conſtance, my old friend's daughter?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You will probably find her in the ſtudy—poor Conſtance takes the humbleneſs of her ſituation too much to heart.

div.stage: Exit L. Flip. Cheat. and Wid.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Colonel, I knew the father of Conſtance intimately, a ſtout fellow and ſerved his country long and well—he ſerved abroad—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
Strict honour was his principle—but alas, he experienced that was not the medium
to promotion-—ſo finding carpet ſoldiers like you promoted over his head, he went to India.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This widow of mine, Ordeal, hath a prolific flow of wit and ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Yes, and egad I thought ſhe ſtruck you dumb—ſhe has a prolific tongue too, ſharp as the arrow of a Bornean Indian, and tipp'd with poiſon; your union with her will be happy—perfectly happy—though I recollect ſhe compared you to a cuckoo, a bird of omen; yes, a cuckoo is a very ominous bird—pray, Colonel, is the widow ſkilled in augury?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Damn your cuckoo! but your ſpeaking of augury reminds me of a circumſtance at the ſiege of Prague—a flock of rooks—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I muſt go pay my compliments to Conſtance▪

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: At the ſiege of Prague—when the Pruſſian grenadiers advanced (holds Ordeal)

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Were you at the ſiege, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My regiment was there—I have ſerved my country.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Oh, yes, you have done great ſervice to your country—at home—by cenſuring thoſe who have fought for her abroad.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: SIR, I muſt ſay you preſume too far.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I ſaw your ladyſhip and admired, and if that be preſumption, who is free from it? admiration naturally produced a more tender emotion—I communicated my feelings to Mrs. Muſlin;—Mrs. Muſlin reported them to your ladyſhip, and your ladyſhip, with a mind, liberal as your perſon is elegant, permits me to throw myſelf at your feet.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You have miſconſtrued the liberty I allowed—my houſe is always open to perſons of faſhion, and as a viſitor only I expected you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nay, madam, your privy counſellor informed me I ſhould be admitted into the interior cabinet, and your principal lady in waiting introduced me in form accordingly.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And ſhall I call her now, ſir, to ſhew you the way back? (aſide) pleaſant impudent fellow.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You are not ſo cruel—I ſee pardon beaming from your eye, and frolic ſmiling on your cheek.

p.hi: And ſhould I pardon, from that inſtant, the ſervile ſuppliant, now at my feet, would loſe all ſenſe of obligation, and from the miſtreſs's ſlave aſpire to be her tyrant.
I neither deſire to be ſlave or tyrant, but to love upon equal terms—you conſent—I read it in your eyes—and I am ſecret as the grave.
Secret you may be, but it is not the mere colour of reputation can protect a woman's honor.—I might perhaps carry on an intrigue with ſecrecy, but my mind—

Upon my ſoul I have no deſign upon your ladyſhip's mind, my heart is captivated; and if I did not totally miſunderſtand my good friend, and your ladyſhip's very good friend, Mrs. Muſlin, a certain perſon, (whom modeſty will not permit me to name) is not totally indifferent in your opinion

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: (within.) Grace, where is your lady?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Sir Buzzard's voice!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (within) My lady, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, your lady, ma'am!—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (ſpeaking very loud) She is in her own room, ſir, but I believe not yet dreſs'd—I'll let her know you want her, ſir.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: As I hope to be ſaved, here is my maſter, and in one of his gruff humours, quite in a tantrum—the gentleman cannot go out that way—follow me.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Into the next room—make haſte

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I go, perhaps into the interior cabinet—This alarm I truſt will convince your ladyſhip that in love, as in war, delays are dangerous—Go on, Mrs. Grace.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: What an infernal life I lead!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: What has rais'd the ſtorm now?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Why aſk!—you know I am married—and married to you—I am my own maſter, and hate impertinent queſtions—I have loſt my money—I am glad of it.—Oh! I wiſh I had never married

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (ſighs) And I, with all my heart▪

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yet you leaped at my offer—you were glad to ſnatch at me—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Who I? I was ſeduced into the match!—have I not brought reputation to your houſe, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Reputation to my houſe!—you have turn'd my houſe topſy turvy; inſide out; you have irritated me into a complication of complaints, and reduced my fortune to galloping decay—have fretted me down to a mere ſkeleton.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p:
Sir, ſome reſpect is due to my birth;—I am daughter to a nobleman, and
till honoured with my hand, your family could not boaſt a drop of blood in their veins.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: No blood in their veins! I, indeed have loſt both fleſh and blood; no blood in my veins!—Have I not lent your brother money—your uncle, money—your couſins money!—which of your honourable, or right honourable relations are out of my debt?—If I had no blood in my veins, how the devil have you and yours bled me ſo plentifully?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I deſpiſe your meanneſs—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Your family are leeches—I could never ſhake them off.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Sir, your connexion with me was an honor, which with all your land and wealth, you had no right to expect. What was your family before your union with me?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Men and women.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Could they boaſt antiquity?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, my grandfather lived to ninety—my father to eighty-ſix.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You married me—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: To perpetuate my family—are you ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: No, I am not ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I know it, I know it.—I know it.

p.hi: My anceſtors can be traced to the Normans—the Danes—the Saxons.
Which only proves you have ſprung from pirates and invaders; but what is it to me if you were related to the Picts, the Scots, or the Romans?—I am a Savage!
Yes, you are a ſavage indeed—
And the Savages let me tell you, are the oldeſt and pureſt blood in the country.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (aſide) How ſhall I get rid of him—Sir Buzzard, you don't intend to ſtay here I hope?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You hope ſo, do you?—I am glad of that, then here I ſhall have a comfortable nap. (ſits down and compoſes himſelf)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (aſide) I'll raiſe the ſpirit of contradiction to ſend him off (draws a chair and ſits by him) now that is kind, thanks for your company, and I'll read, or ſing a lullaby to compoſe you; ſhall I kiſs you?—come now, ſmile my dear. (takes off his hat)

sp.speaker: Sir Buz:
sp.p: I hate ſmiling, ſmiling is the cunning covering of deceit, (riſing) and kiſſing—am I in a habit of conſtitution for kiſſing?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Am not I your wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I feel you are—do not roll your baſiliſks—they have loſt their faſcinating powers.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: But you ſhall not go—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Not go!—I am maſter of my own houſe!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Then I will be miſtreſs of my time;—I may find a companion.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: With all my heart—a woman who would keep her huſband at home, is worſe than a corn on his foot, there is no ſtirring at eaſe for her!—O that mine were cut off.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You will go before me though, I ſhall wear weeds for my love—your face looks this inſtant pale as marble, and I can ſee "Here lieth Sir Buzzard Savage," written on your forehead.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I am ill it is true.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Ill! you have a mortal blackneſs under your eyes.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Eh! What!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Do not ſtare ſo—it alarms me!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: My head ſwims!—I feel a palpitation here, juſt upon my temple.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: A dangerous ſymptom.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I know it, and you are glad of it. Oh, Lord! I ſhall preſently be enrolled on Death's liſt of Bath patients, who die where they come to live for the recovery of their health. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Now to deliver my poor diſtreſſed ſwain from confinement. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
Nay, my nonpareil—my ſweeteſt, deareſt of all girls, you may believe every word I ſay.
Lady FLIPPANT appears liſtning at a door in the ſcene.
I have lov'd you—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Love me!—dear ſir!—Well, whether you ſpeak truth or no, I like to hear you ſay ſo—yet, I fear you are falſe-hearted, it was my lady you came to viſit.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Your lady! no, no, child, you were the object, and I got myſelf introduced to the lady, that I might with more eaſe become intimate with the maid.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Cannot believe that—my lady is much hand ſomer than I—What a fine complexion!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Mere rouge!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: White teeth!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: For which ſhe's obliged to the Dentiſt—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Charming hair!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: All falſe.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Then, what polite converſation!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Pſha, child ſhe has not the native bloom of your cheeks, the nectarine of your lip, the pearl of your teeth, the natural curl of your treſſes, nor the wit of your imagination.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (aſide) How I likes to hear him praiſe me and abuſe my lady!—and you really love me?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Moſt devoutly—could we not retire to a more private chamber? (ſhews a purſe.)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Swear you'll not be falſe hearted.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: By Jupiter, Venus, Cupid, and all the Gods and Goddeſſes, never (ſhakeſ the purſe)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Then hear me ſwear (lays her hand upon the purſe) by this purſe (takes it) I like you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Take it my girl—take it.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: And by this ring, I'll (lays her hand on his ring)

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My dear don't ſwear ſo often—but kiſs me huſſey—I have a ſecret to tell you.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: A ſecret! but may not that ſecret ſpeak for itſelf hereafter, and diſcover all. (Lady Flippant comes forward.) Dear ma'am you can't think how the gentleman has been praiſing your ladyſhip's complexion, teeth, hair, and I don't know what.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes, I was praiſing your ladyſhip's—I—I—I—don't know what.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: There's no impediment now, ſir, to your retiring, and I requeſt you will inſtantly withdraw.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
For the preſent I ſubmit to your rigid and peremptory ſentence;—it is my way never to deny or palliate my faults. When I travel in purſuit of pleaſure, I always take a view of ſuch beautiful ſeats as lie before me, and for the life of me, I could not help caſting an eye on this little ſnug box, which lay ſo convenient to your ladyſhip's manſion-houſe.
Ex. Welford.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
I hope your ladyſhip will excuſe me;—I thought I was doing no harm,—I thought your ladyſhip diſmiſſed the gentleman, and your ladyſhip knows we chambermaids have the ſame claim to our lady's caſt lovers, as to their caſt cloaths.
Exit Grace.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Order chairs, and tell my ſiſter I'll attend her to—Devil take the fellow, yet I admire him for his impudence.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter NICHOLAS and DOUGLAS, diſguiſed in a ſhabby Highland Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: And ſo you were recommended by old Corderius, the ſchoolmaſter, to teach our young lady the Latin lingo.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Yes; to inſtruct her in the reediments of the dead languages.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Dead languages! do you mean the languages ſpoken in the other world? for ecod ſhe can chatter glibby enough in the living tongue.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I am to inſtruct her, man, in Greek and Latin.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
Greek and Latin! will not that teach her ſtrology and conjuration?
Enter ORDEAL. Here, Sir, is Mr. a—a—What's your name, Scotchey?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Alexander M'Claſſic.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: He's Mr. M'Claſſic, come from Mr. Corderius to learn Miſs Clary the dead languages, which he has got alive at his tongue's end.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Here, Sir, are my credentials.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: My friend Corderius gives you an excellent character, young man, for honeſty, and literary abilities, and you may begin with your pupil when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: He has began with her already▪

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: You are perfect maſter of the claſſics, I preſume.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: My father keept an academy, where I firſt acquired the roodiments, and after I matriculated at Aberdeen; there I made an intimate acquantance with the philoſophers, Chriſtian, and Heathen,—the logicians, mathematicians, aſtronomers, navigators, botaniſts, chemiſts, and aw the tribe of nateral philoſophers.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What a number of ſcholars are in Aberdeen!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Be ſilent, fool.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: As to the claſſics, I am maiſter of Homer, Xenophon, Sophocles, Seneca, Virgil, Ovid, Terence, Salluſt, Livy and Horace.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Have you learned all thoſe gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Silence, you inquiſitive puppy.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I teach them aw, and will make the young lady miſtreſs of them aw.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Miſtreſs of them all! Ecod ſhe'll never remember half of her ſervant's names! but o' tag, rag, and bobtail; how comes it that with all thoſe ſcholars you've taught, you go ſo poorly? Ecod your cloaths are all in jeopardy. He! he! he!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Silence. Go you, ſirrah, and call miſs Clara.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
I go—I go—I go—I go—I go—let me ſee—he teaches muſicians, magicians, and phyſicians—and he'll teach her conjuration and ſtar-gazing—and—mum.
Exit Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: You are, I preſume, Sir, a ſcholar.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I never deny my ignorance—it is my misfortune, and a man ſhould only be aſhamed of his faults,—I do not underſtand a word of any language but my native tongue, except a few phraſes I have picked up,—but I have read moſt Engliſh authors; born in poverty I was debarred the benefit of a liberal education,—I am candid—that's my way.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: This is a common caſe.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: No doubt one half of the literati are unlettered, and like light or Birmingham guineas, paſs for more than they are worth.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: You intend to mary the lady yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: And you have ſecluded her frae company, aw that was judicious—be cautious what men you introduce to her.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Yes; and women too,

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p:
That's right,—recreations which prudence
prohibits at home, and decency denies the exerciſe of in public, may eaſily be enjoyed at the preevate houſe of a confidential friend.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
You are right, there are many obliging, convenient, liberal-hearted, female beauty brokers, who ſupport elegance and expence by trading in a contraband commerce of the ſexes.
Enter CLARA and NICHOLAS. Well, my girl,—your tutor has given you a leſſon, I underſtand.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. (Loud knocking).

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
Who the devil is at the door?—I believe they have got a battering-ram, and are going to ſtorm us after the manner of the Greeks and Romans.
Exit Nich.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Such ſilks, and ruſtlings!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: There are cork rumps—hoops and high heels in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Who knocks at the door?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: They are covered with paint, patches and pomatum.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Who knock'd at the door?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Falſe hair, curls and perfumes!—don't blame me, they came upon me unawares; I puſh'd, and they puſh'd,—but they puſh'd harder, and overturned me.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Who overturned you?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: They are full of flirtation, and giggling, and bedizened with gauze and ribbands; Lady Savage and her ſiſter, with their long tails ſweeping behind.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Lady Savage and her ſiſter! Lady Devil and her imp!—Where are they?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Running all over the houſe—up ſtairs and down ſtairs, to and fro,—in and out—backwards and forwards—round about—here and there, and every where.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I am not at home,—there is no body at home—we are all out—I'll retire to my cloſet; you will ſtep with me, Mr. M'Claſſic, and do you, my lamb, lock yourſelf up to avoid 'em.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: He, he, he,—here is a bluſter,—Ecod we ſhall have rare ſport.

div.stage: Enter LADY FLIPPANT and the WIDOW.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Where, my dear, in ſuch haſte?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot ſtay—muſt I not go, Nicholas?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes, you muſt go,—go—go—go

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Be not alarmed, miſs, we are Mr. Ordeal's intimate friends.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes, miſs, they are our intimate friends.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Come to viſit you, my dear.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes; they are come to viſit us,—my dear.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Where is Sir Ordeal?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Out—out—out (Points to the cloſet.) (Aſide) we ſhall have ſwinging fun.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ladies, farewell. (going.)

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie, my dear,—it would be impolite to leave company.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Miſs Clary,—Manners makes the man—we are teaching her the Latin lingo.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Are you very happy, my dear, on being on the verge of matrimony?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Speak, my dear. (Lady Flippant, and the Widow, ſtand on each ſide of Clara.)

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I cannot ſay I'm very happy; nor I cannot ſay I am diſpleaſed; I do not wiſh to be married, nor have I any objection to a huſband—Heigho!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: But to confeſs the truth, you have no deſire to marry Mr. Ordeal, he is ſuch an old fellow; though if addreſſed by a handſome, wealthy, good natured youth, you'd—Heigho!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Do not ſpeak diſreſpectfully of my guardian—he is very kind to me.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I approve your prudence in preferring an old lover to a young one; after marriage you will no longer be confined like an infant;—then you will enjoy ſuch pleaſure in making his money fly, and in ſeeing him approach the grave.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But for fear he ſhould live too long, be ſure you get him a phyſician.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: A phyſician! O, death!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: My guardian has taught me how a married lady ought to conduct herſelf.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Let us hear, my dear pretty creature.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I have it by heart; he has taught me, that all young men are cunning and deceitful, and that I muſt never liſten to or believe their flattering tongues; that a man and his wife are one perſon, and ſhould act as if inſpired by one ſoul!—that a wife ſhould not complain of her huſband to her moſt intimate friends, nor form any connexions without his approbation.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: There's inſtruction for you; you ſee we take care of her ſoul.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Moreover, he has taught me, that in private a wif ſhould receive no company without
her huſband's knowledge, and in public ſhould not think herſelf protected but by his preſence; that ſhe ſhould obey him in all things, and place her higheſt delight in making him happy.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Theſe were the duties of a wife in the laſt century,—but we will inſtruct you in the duties of a wife, who would cut a figure in the polite circles of the preſent day▪—Siſter, begin.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Muſt conſider matrimony a means to increaſe liberty, and defy ſcandal.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Muſt retain your favourite ciciſbeo, confidante, maid ſervant and footman.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: That will be, I.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: See whom you pleaſe, where you pleaſe, and when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: That muſt be very pleaſant!—go on.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Muſt be miſtreſs of your own hours,—turn day into night, and night into day.—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Keep a ſeparate purſe, a ſeparate carriage, and a ſeparate bed.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Never attend to oeconomy, but ſink, play, and ſquander your money, to the laſt ſhilling, and ſtretch your huſband's credit to the utmoſt.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Here is work cut out for mantua-makers and milleners.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You muſt always diſſimulate in converſation with your huſband, and when you cannot deceive you muſt inſiſt—if he oppoſes your will, rant, and laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And if theſe fail, accuſe him of cruelty, ſigh, ſob, weep, ſcream out, and fall into fits.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I can contain no longer!—out of my houſe!—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Shame! Shame! What, liſtening to the private converſation of ladies?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Private converſation! open, abominable inſtruction,—how can you anſwer to your conſcience, for attempting to poiſon a young creature's morals!—retire, retire, my lamb.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Farewell, ladies.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Adieu, pretty Clara.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And remember our inſtructions.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Inſtructions!—down-right libertine principles!—you may laugh, ladies,—you may laugh. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Perhaps the ladies think their beauty ſufficient excuſe for their levity,—but ah, they are wrong—naething can atone for want of delicacy, without which there can be nae charms in the face, nae elegance in the perſon.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ordeal, your moſt obedient—call'd at your ladyſhip's houſe, and Miſs Conſtance inform'd me you were on a viſit here.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: We came to ſee Mr. Ordeal's pure nature, and he has affronted us!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Affronted!—impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Haud your tongue, lady, haud your tongue!—levity degrades a woman, however her name may be elevated by birth, teetle, or fortin.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: A man.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes, and a ſcholar ecod!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: (to the women) Out of my houſe!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I'll prophecy for your comfort, if you marry Clara ſhe'll ſoon draw a compariſon between your winter frown, and the ſummer ſmiles of a pretty fellow.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I deſpiſe your prophecy—Oracles have long ſince ceaſed; when they exiſted the devil ſpoke through them, which may be your ladyſhip's caſe.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ordeal, take care, I wear a ſword.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I weer a ſword.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Do you daar echo my words?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Do you daar echo my words?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Knock out his teeth with one of your hard ones.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Raſcal (raiſes his hand).

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Raſcal! hear firſt, and ſtrike after,—you appear an officer, but I am convinced you are nae ſoldier; touch but a hair o' my heed wi your hand, and the dee'l gang away wi my ſoul, gin I dinna ſplit you through the crown.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, ſhall I bring him the old broad ſword.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There was juſt ſuch a fellow as this at the Havannah—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: There were ſeveral ſuch fellows at the Havannah, and ſuch fellows only could have beaten the brave fellows who defended it,—were you there?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My regiment did ſervice there—and if it had not been for a damn'd ague,—but no matter,—I overlook this fellow's inſolence,—but Mr. Ordeal, you have been too ſevere on the ladies

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Too ſevere on the ladies—I am your echo again—zounds, do you take the man for a Shrove-Tide cock, ſet up to receive blows without returning them?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Let's go, we are not likely to receive protection from the Colonel.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I ken, madam, what you are.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Stand off, fellow—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Theſe are ladies of honour.—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Their honour, like your courage, is in their own poſſeſſion, but remember the character of both is in the opinion of others.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Do you hear the fellow?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: He's mad, and not worth notice.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Were I Clara, I ſhould prefer a young Indian, though ſure of being his widow; and burning with him in a month, to living with you for an age.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ordeal, you ſhall anſwer this—but—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: But what dare you ſay?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Say—I ſay—my immediate duty is to attend the ladies.

div.stage: Exit Colonel, Lady Flippant and Widow.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: My brave Caledonian! (ſhakes hands) but here, here, ſtep out and get yourſelf new rigged— (gives Douglas money).

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes, he is out of feather and wants pluming.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: But you, you ſirrah, if ever you let thoſe women enter my doors again, out you go—oh, what a fierce beaſt, and a perilous enemy to the commonwealth, is a wicked woman. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Lady FLIPPANT SAVAGE and GRACE.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: SHALL I introduce the Gentleman, my lady?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Yes,—no,—yes, Grace.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I like the gentleman, becauſe he likes your ladyſhip,—and that ſhews him a man of taſte—I go.— (going)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Stay, Grace,—let me conſider, this interview may be attended with all the ill conſequences of an illicit correſpondence.—what are you muſing on Grace?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I am thinking how very ugly Sir Buzzard is in compariſon with your ladyſhip's lover.—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Sir Buzzard's plainneſs, Grace, is not his worſt fault,—it is his peeviſh aſperity of diſpoſition renders him odious to me,—Grace, I will not ſee this gentleman, it will endanger my reputation.—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Lay, my lady, but conſider, my reputation, my honour is pledged,—he is a delightful creature.—Then conſider what an airy, nice dreſſed gentleman he is—and conſider, Sir Buzzard wears flannel under-waiſtcoats, and ſwanſkin ſtockings.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Can I ever again face Sir Buzzard?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
If I was your ladyſhip, I would not face my lover too ſuddenly,—no, I would recline
upon the ſopha,— (ſits) loſt in thinking,—ſo,—with my fan ſhading my face thus, and every thing about me. degagee.—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You ſay he waits.—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Or when the dear man approach'd, turn ſhort—ſtrike him with the full flaſh of my charms, and ſcream out. Ah!— (ſcreams and ſtarts up.)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Are you mad, girl?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: A thouſand pardons, my lady, but proteſt I am beſide myſelf. Exit. Grace.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: There is no retracting, and I think I will take him by ſurpriſe.—I'll keep up the appearance of reſentment, and have the ſatisfaction of hearing him humbly plead for pardon— (ſits, with ber back to the door)

div.stage: Enter GRACE, and WELFORD full dreſſed.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Now you muſt acknowledge I am your friend.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My ſweet girl, I do acknowledge it— Exit. Grace. A fine figure! (taps lady Flippant on the ſhoulder,—ſhe ſtarts) Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Heaven defend me!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Not from an ardent lover!—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Aſide) I cannot ſcold the fellow he looks ſo pleaſant!—Pray, Sir, by what warrant do you come here?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I underſtand from Mrs. Muſlin, by warrant from your own lips,—but the warrant is incompleat till your ladyſhip has affix'd the privy ſeal to it (offers to kiſs her).

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: A married woman can grant nothing without the conſent of her huſband.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Well thought on; but I do not come unprepared, man and wife are one perſon, and when a married lady gives me reaſon to think a tete-a-tete would not be diſagreeable, I always take care to bring my authority along with me.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe a lady ſhould acknowledge your authority;—your inclinations, I imagine, Sir, could not eaſily be attach'd to a ſingle object.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes they could,—though I candidly acknowledge I entertain an affection for the whole ſex.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Then there is an individual you prefer to the whole ſex?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: There is.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Handſome?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Senſible?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And you really prefer her—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: If I denied it I ſhould be inſincere and unworthy your attention.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And pray, Sir, may I enquire, who is the favourite fair?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nay, the leſs we ſay, or think of her, the better, ſhe is abſent—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,—I perceive ſhe is abſent— (walks about) and you too are abſent.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe is abſent,—and—Sir Buzzard is abſent, and we are together,—and you are a fine woman,—and I am—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A man,—a young man, not a very ill made man, and a very well dreſs'd man, with a briſk flow of ſpirits, a warm heart, and a ſoul which at this inſtant vibrates with ſenſibility.

sp.speaker: Sir Buzzard
sp.p: (within). I ſay it is falſe, I left all the papers in London—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I proteſt Sir Buzzard is at the door—you muſt be concealed again—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Unfortunate! (ſhe puſhes him in)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You cannot get out of that room till I pleaſe— (ſits)

div.stage: Enter Sir BUZZARD SAVAGE, and GRACE walking lame.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Oh, mercy, Sir, you have ruin'd me; oh, my lady, my lady, oh, oh, I ſhall faint with pain; juſt when I got to the door, there was my maſter, and not knowing it, I run plump againſt him, and he trod upon my foot,—oh,—but it is much better.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: (ſits) A meſſenger is come down from London for the title deeds of Proſpect Farm,—do you know where they are?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: What ſhould I know about your muſty parchments?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Why not?—you ſpend the rents faſt enough—but I remember now, they are in a box that lies in the wardrobe in that room, and—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: La, Sir,—I will get it.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You are not tall enough to reach it.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
But I can ſtand on a chair, Sir, though I need not do that,—our new footman is in the cloſet ſettling your cloaths, Sir.—yes, Sir,—
our new footman, Sir, is in the cloſet ſett'ling your honour's wardrobe, and he'll help me.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (aſide) What can ſhe mean? ſhall I deſire Grace to bring the box out to you?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: No, let the footman bring it out, I have not ſeen him yet,—Grace, bid the fellow bring in the box.

sp.speaker: Grace
sp.p: (within) He's taking it down, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Leave it in the cloſet, I muſt get ſome other papers out of the ſcrutore (riſes).

div.stage: Enter GRACE and WELFORD in a Livery, with a box.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Come, young man, I'll get you my lady's cards for Wedneſday's route, and they muſt be delivered immediately.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (aſide) What a metamorphoſis!—you'll be expeditious.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: A good looking fellow;—but ſtand off;—he is enough to ſuffocate a man with perfume! What's your name, Civet Cat?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: (in a ſtrong brogue) What's my name? I was chriſten'd Patrick, your honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: An Iriſhman!—eh,—heav'n knows we had blunders enough in t • e family before,— (looking on the box) —this is the wrong box.

div.stage: Exit Sir Buzzard into the cloſet.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Yes, we have all got into the wrong box (aſide).

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: When next we meet— Exit.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Nothing could be more lucky, my lady,—the new livery that came home for your laſt footman George, lay in the bottom of my maſter's wardrobe. I muſt ſee him ſafe out—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: This is too mortifying, it hurts my pride—had I met a man of a generous diſpoſition—but here comes my torment, and reflection flies.

div.stage: Enter Sir BUZZARD with WELFORD's Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I have found more than I ſought for, Lady Flippant;—who am I to thank for this addition to my wardrobe?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Theſe cloaths!—you mean theſe cloaths!—he, he, he,—they are really very pretty cloaths—you like them, my dear?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: No, I don't like them, my dear; and who the devil did they come from, my dear? and to whom do they belong, my dear?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Elegant manufacture!—nothing like it made in England.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Where did they come from?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Paris.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Who owns them?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: They are your cloaths, my love!—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Mine! Did you ever ſee me wear ſuch frippery?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Yes, yours poſitively; but I did not intend you ſhould have ſeen them—they were ſmuggled.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Smuggled!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Yes, ſmuggled from Paris, by my milliner, and ſent here for the purpoſe of ornamenting you, my ſweet love!—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Sweet love!—now that's fulſome—yet thou art my ſweet love!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Am I?— (ſmiling.)

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, like an apothecary's doſe,—my bitter ſweet.—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: How ill-natur'd!—but no matter, you ſhall wear theſe cloaths at the ball this evening.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You ſhall.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Damn me if I do.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, then I'll ſend 'em back.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: They ſhall not be ſent back, I begin to like them,—a good colour, and not too gaudy.—I'll keep them.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Keep them!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, and wear them.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Wear them,—where?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: At the ball this evening.—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I fear you will take cold.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You wiſh I ſhould take cold, but I will not take cold,—and I will wear the cloaths; you lay out a revenue on your back, and I will, at leaſt for this once, follow your example.—I'll keep the cloaths, and go to the ball in them this evening.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Aſide.) The ſmuggled cloaths are fairly forfeited.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Dinner, my Lady!— (ſeeing the cloaths) bleſs me!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Apart.) Silence, all is well.—Sir Buzzard you ſee found the cloaths I ordered Mrs. Muſlin to procure him from Paris.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Well, I am ſure, Sir, my Lady has fitted you nicely, and I admire her taſte, that I do; but will you wear them, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, wear them, Sir!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Not 'till after dinner, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Directly, Mrs. Prate,—I will ſurprize the company in them:—let dinner be kept back.

div.stage: Exit Sir Buzzard with the cloaths.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: It was good luck he did not find the gentleman's ſword—yet little matter if he had, for intriguing with an incumbrance about him; but how ſhall I get him away?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Poor ſoul! he muſt have patience—contrive to convey him through the garden, to a chair, he may pretend he is a ſervant taken ill, which will blind ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Well thought on,—my Lady's no fool, but ſhe muſt be a great fool indeed, who could not make a fool of a huſband.

div.head: SCENE II,—Ordeal's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: He, he, he, lack a daiſy, Miſs Clara—the Scotchman looks gaily in his new cloaths,—he is a brave youth,—what a leg (looks at his leg) —but I have got more of the calf.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Yes, a good deal more calf, Nicholas;—but what can be the reaſon that while he's teaching me, he ſighs as piteouſly as if in pain,—it goes to my heart to hear him without being able to give him eaſe.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why—why—ecod now, Miſs Clary, when you ſpeak to me, it makes me ſigh, and gives me the heart-burn.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What would you have me do, good Nicholas?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What would I have you do? I'll tell you—ecod I cannot—but I'll tell you what the Scotchman ought to do—he,—he ought.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Ecod, he ought to,—to—Sugar and Honey!—what red lips you have!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What ought he to do?—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What ought he to do!—why he ought to—how old are you?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Do not tantalize me, Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Well, I will tell you, he ought to—bleſs my eyes, what a fine face ſhe has!—he ought to—he ought to—what pretty buckles yours are!—he ought to,—well, ſhake hands, I will tell you (takes her hand) ſoft as ſattin,—he ought to—ecod, I ſhould like to do it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Do what?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I mean no offence—but he ought to— (kiſſes his hand) that's what he ought—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh, ſhame, Nicholas,—ſhame.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What ſhame!—liſten to me,—and I won't go behind the buſh with you—my maſter is a fool, and thinks nobody knows any thing but himſelf—Now, when I ſee a young man and a young lady together,—and hear them ſigh, and ſee them ogle—why, I ſigh myſelf, and I—I—ecod, I know what's what.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And what is it you know, Nicholas?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: That the Scotch ſcholard loves you, and that you like the Scotch ſcholard—I'ze been in love, and I'ze never think of it, but—Oh, but I can not tell you how it diſturbs me— (whiſtles.)

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And I am diſturbed too—heigh ho!

div.head: SONG.
div.l: What wakes this new pain in my breaſt?
This ſenſe that lay dormant before?
Lie ſtill, buſy flutt'rer, and reſt,
The peace of my boſom reſtore.
What wakes, &c.
Why trickles in ſilence the tear,
This ſighing—ah! what does it mean?
This mixture of hope and of fear,
Where once all was mild and ſerene.—
What wakes, &c.
Some pleaſingly anxious alarm,
Now warms and then freezes my heart,
Some ſoft irriſiſtible charm,
Alternate gives pleaſure and ſmart.
What wakes, &c.

div.stage: Enter ORDEAL and DOUGLAS, in a neat Scotch Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Clara, your tutor tells me, you make an aſtoniſhing progreſs in your Grammar, and I am to hear you ſpeak a leſſon,—bring chairs, Nicholas (they ſit).

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Ha you got your Grammar, lady?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I have been ſtudying my laſt leſſon (takes a Grammar from her pocket).

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Be ſeated, lady, (they ſit).

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
Modeſt creature!—how the bluſh mantles on her cheek!—don't be aſhamed, Clary—Mac Claſſic (takes Douglas aſide) what a ſubject
for ſpeculation—ſhe is an orange tree, poſſeſſing at once the ſprightly verdure of the ſpring, the ſweet bloſſom of the ſummer, and the ripe fruit of autumn. It revives me to look on her.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: It revives us to look on you.—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: What think you of her eyes,—they ſhoot arrows of deſire into the heart, but on her lips lies an honied ſalve to heal the wound.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: (agitated) Will you hear her repeat a leſſon?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: See her mouth, a door of coral, opening to a colonade of pearl.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Then her boſom, your honour.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Where the devil is the fellow going? (ſhakes him).

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: (aſide) My ſpirits are ſo agitated, I ſhall betray myſelf.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Come, my lamb—begin.—there is a mild creature, wax of my own faſhioning, and I have moulded her into the very temper of my affections.—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: She can give you Latin for every thing about you.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Reſtrain your tongue, ſirrah. Go on with your leſſon, ſweeteſt, and never mind this fellow.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: (Tenderly) Amo, I love, (looks at Douglas) amas, thou loveſt, (looks at Ordeal) amat, he loves!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: (Sighs). Oh!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Amamus, we love. Oh! (ſighs)

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: He, he, he, amo—I love!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Silence, raſcal!—but, Mac Claſſic, are the firſt leſſons in Lilly's grammar upon love?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Aw grammars begin wi it, Sir—becauſe love is the primoeval principle of nature.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: He, he, he!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Out of the room, you ſcoundrel!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I go, zir. Amo, I love, amo, you love, amo, he loves, amo, we love,—he, he, he!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Shall we proceed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: If you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: There are three poor people below you deſired to call.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I ſhall return directly.— (Nicholas following) Where are you going? Stay here,—Clara may want ſomething—you'll give her a new leſſon now, Mr. M'Claſſick—I think ſhe has got enough of amo and amas.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
Zooks! he's jealous, zure as a gun, and left me here to watch you—but ecod, I'll be no ſpoil-ſport—ſo teach away—I love, you love—he loves.
Exit Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What are you muſing on?—I like to hear your inſtructions when we are alone.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: (aſide) To ſeduce ſuch innocence would be damnable; when you are married to Mr. Ordeal, my inſtructions will no longer pleaſe,—you love him?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I do indeed, as much as if he was my father,—but I never think of him when you are preſent.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Then you love him from gratitude?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Juſt ſo!—could I have any other motive
—If there be any other kind of love, I wiſh you'd let me know it.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: There is another kind,—give me your hand—there is a love known by its effects, it beats on the pulſe, trembles on the breath, gives eyes to the thoughts, and thoughts to the eyes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: O la! then I'm ſure you are in love, for your eyes ſpeak and laugh,—why did you touch my hand?—indeed—indeed, I'm afraid I have taken it from you—I hope there's no danger in it.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Love is the child of deſire, nurs'd by delight—weaned by inconſtancy, conſumed by neglect, kill'd by diſſembling, and buried by ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: How cruel to kill it.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: But then 'tis the parent of jealouſy, the diſuniter of friendſhip, and cauſe of diſobedience; an arbitrary tyrant of the mind, that triumphs over wiſdom, tramples upon prudence, and vanquiſhes even virtue.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: O, you fright me with that deſcription.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: But where virtue is the baſis of this paſſion, it produces the utmoſt happineſs enjoyed on earth, and gives mortals a taſte of heaven!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Now that is delightful! and to tell you the truth I have heard my guardian ſpeak of it, but I could never feel it in his hand as I did in your's; he ſays—"love is fire full of cold—honey full of gall—and pleaſure full of pain;"—but I ſee he knows nothing of the matter;—are you really in love?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, deeply—deeeply;—but why do you aſk?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Becauſe—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Here comes Mr. Ordeal.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: (Aſide) I wiſh he was in Jericho.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Very well—very well—here Nicholas!—where's the raſcal? Clara, my dear, ſeek him, and give orders for dinner, there's a good girl. (Kiſſes her hand).

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Heigho! (looks at Douglas)—(to Ordeal) I obey, Sir.
Exit Clara.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: An amiable, modeſt creature, Mr. M'Claſſic—nothing ardent in her diſpoſition, has no more idea of love than an infant, yet a charming fertilizing conſtitution, but chaſte as ice,—"her heart like the ſalamander—cold, cold, in the midſt of flame."

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Virtue beams in her een, and animates her countenance; like the finiſhing touches of the painter, it enlivens the portrait, and increaſes the beauty of the object.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Poetically conceiv'd, and prettily pronounc'd;—yes, ſhe ſhrinks from the touch like the ſenſitive plant—you have a prolific imagination, Mr. M'Claſſic, conſidering you come from a northern climate (viewing Douglas) —yet Mr. M'Claſſic, there is no judging of a woman's chaſtity, who has never been in the way of temptation.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Very true, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: And women are virtuous in proportion to the temptations they withſtand.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: A juſt concluſion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Then you think it would be difficult to find a young inexperienced girl proof againſt promiſes, ſighs and tears—and who could withſtand the cunning inſinuations of a lover.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Well, I think differently; I think I could truſt Clara—but ſhe's a nonpareil—yes, cool as a cucumber in a hot bed—yet not prone to vegetation—but M'Claſſic, I have an experiment to make, and you muſt aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Command me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Clara I think is a pure lamb.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Sir, there can be no doubt; but you were ſpeaking of an experiment, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I have fortified her mind with morals, which will prove a ſhield to her by day, and a breaſt-plate by night.—But the experiment—you muſt be my inſtrument.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: In what reſpect, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: To ſound the depth of her inclinations,—to feel how the pulſe of her affection beats towards me.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: If ſhe ſhould not like me—but that is a point for future conſideration—if ſhe ſhould like me, I will marry her in the morning.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Marry her, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Yes, marry her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: And in the morning. O my heart! and muſt I loſe her after all?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: In the morning—I have had a ſpecial licence ſometime—yes, ſhe loves me—I know ſhe loves me—and ſoon as we have dined, I will go to Sir Buzzard's, to engage him and his friends to attend the ceremony. In the mean time you muſt try the experiment—come-in to dinner, and I'll give you further inſtructions.

div.head: SCENE I. Sir Buzzard's.
div.stage: Enter Sir BUZZARD and CHEATERLY. Sir Buzzard in Welford's Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: CONSIDER, Sir Buzzard, we are in danger of a diſcoveey every ininſtant.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: What can I do?—Would you have me court the girl for you? Beſides, this buſineſs raiſes a qualm in my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Conſcience!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, conſcience!—my conſcience cannot boaſt ſuch extenſive latitude and longitude as your's,—you have a convenient conſcience, it ſtretches or contracts like India rubber; your conſcience is a ſervant of all work—which you diſcharge at a moment's warning.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: May the fire of a platoon never again raiſe my ſpirits, but it would be better for a man to attack a breach daily and on a forlorn hope, than to ſit down before a coquet.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: "Have you ever attacked a breach, Colonel?"

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You hear he has attacked a widow, and upon a forlorn hope."

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I ſay, Sir, your ſiſter is a coquet.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I ſay ſhe is a downright jilt. He who confides in the ſex will be deceived—I deſpiſe them.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Yet keep a girl in a corner.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: "But not from affection to the girl, I keep her becauſe it pleaſes my humour, and vexes my wife." You know the ſex but ſuperficially; there is my rib, when we married, ſhe was all delicacy and good humour, and from her ſmooth behaviour and oily tongue, I conſidered her a miracle of goodneſs. But the wind ſoon veer'd about, and before the end of the honey-moon blew a rank ſtorm.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: "Talking of ſtorms."

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: "Hear me out—Upon refuſing to indulge her in ſome faſhionable ſubſcriptions, there was a total eclipſe of the amiable, her paſſion ſwell'd like a roaring ſea, producing nothing but fury, outrage and noiſe."

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I forgive you, madam,—I forgive you—being determined to marry Clara in the morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Ordeal, I underſtand they have been abuſing you—but their beſt friends cant 'ſcape their malignity—they have tongues of charcoal, with which they are for ever blackening or burning characters.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I ſhall, immediately ſet off with my bride for London, from whence we will proceed on the grand tour.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Have not I heard you exclaim againſt the grand tour.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
You have heard me exclaim againſt ſending our youth abroad without a proper controul. You have heard me ſay, that on ſuch expeditions they too often contaminate their native virtue and conſtitutions, by bartering the honeſt habits acquired in old England, for the
gew-gaw ornaments, and deſpicable effeminacies of the Continent.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Ordeal, what retinue do you travel with?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: The young Scotchman, Pure Nature's tutor, no doubt will make one.
