sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I wiſh he may not make two; I ſpeak my mind, Ordeal.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What, the Colonel's friend! ſplit you through the crown?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: She is at it again—madam, you ſhould recollect.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then I ſuppoſe you will no longer reſtrain her taſte in dreſs—but allow her to throw off her preſent thin attire, and appear like a faſhionable chriſtian,—in feathers and a hoop.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: A hoop! no—it makes a woman appear like a walking ſphere, encircled from the nadir to the meridian—and if the effeminacy of the men was not ſo well known, one would be apt to imagine that the women were all in a ſtate of—But I will not ſpeak my mind now,—though it is my way.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Coffee is ſerved in the ſaloon, madam.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Have you ſeen Miſs Conſtance? (aſide to the ſervant).

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
I believe, Sir, ſhe is reading in the garden.
Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Sir Buzzard, I admire your dreſs,—you look as fine—as—as the King of Pruſſia in wax-work.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (To the widow) ſhall I have the honor of your hand, Madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, Sir, I ſhall never give my hand to a man who has loſt my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (To Sir Buzzard) —Do you hear that?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: After her.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: After her purſe you mean.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Capricious woman! (running turns round). —I once knew a Major—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Know the Widow, man.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A Major in the forty-ſecond.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Away with you. (they puſh him out).

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: You will excuſe me to the ladies—Conſtance you hear is in the garden, I will ſeek her, and for the laſt time plead my paſſion, but if ſhe perſeveres in rejecting my addreſſes, I have your conſent to carry her by ſtratagem.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
Carry her off any way and I will be ſatisfied.—
Exit Sir Buzzard.

div.head: SCENE II.—A Grotto: Conſtance diſcover'd ſitting, ſleeping, with a handkerchief overher face—a book near her.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Aſleep!—to diſturb her would offend delicacy—and I muſt ſooth her,—I will ſit here till ſhe wakes, here comes one of the ſervants. (Retires).

div.stage: Enter WELFORD. (His ſword under his arm.)

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
How my landlady will laugh to ſee me thus capariſon'd,—a woman ſleeping, by the God of Love!—what a fortunate fellow am I!
—no ſooner does one adventure vaniſh than another preſents itſelf to my view—how gently ſhe breathes,—the gale is reviving,— (ſhe ſighs) a ſigh of ſenſibility,—poor ſoul!—it were pity ſhe ſhould ſigh in vain. Yes, I will ſee her face. (takes off the handkerchief) O, Heaven's!—it is Conſtance—my life!—my heaven!— (embraces her).

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Help!—oh, help!—

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Unhand the lady, villain!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: O, heavens, it is De Courcy!—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Ha! is it you? I have met my bleſſing and my curſe.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: De Courcy!—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I have been your dupe, Sir, and I know it.—Am well inform'd of thoſe combinations by which you defrauded me,—and am determin'd, Sir, to give the law it's courſe.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p:
I ſcorn to retort your aſſertions,—you have been a dupe to your own folly. Pride, and high founding language but ill ſuit with the meanneſs of your appearance, aſſumed for the purpoſe of ſome low intrigue,—metamorphoſe into a gentleman, and I'll enforce ſatisfaction for this inſolence.
Exit Cheaterly.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: O, I ſhall faint.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: My dear love,—pardon the momentary neglect into which paſſion led me.—I have been but one day in England—tomorrow I ſhould have gone for York,—my ſoul was all impatience to ſee you.—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: What, in a livery!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
A livery—yes,—it is a diſguiſe I own, worn for a purpoſe I'll not attempt to palliate
or juſtify—but your appearance like a heavenly viſion inſpires me with virtuous thoughts.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I do not urge an explanation which muſt increaſe your confuſion.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I will explain all another time.—Here comes ſome of the family.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Theſe alarms will ruin my conſtitution,—it was fortunate I took bark this morning, or my whole nervous ſyſtem would be ſhaken to pieces.—Where is this gentleman?—Cheaterly tells me a ſtranger has been rude to you, have you turn'd him out, Patrick?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: (To Ordeal) Sir, I ſhall ſend a letter to your houſe immediately, to which I implore your attention—I am wretched, you were my father's friend.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Madam, if I was not, I am a man, and every thing that affects my fellow-creatures concerns me.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Patrick,—do you hear?—no anſwer,—I ſhall never recover my health,—don't irritate me, raſcal.—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Raſcal!—to whom do you addreſs yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: To you, ſcoundrel.—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why, you deſpicable,—that epithet again, and this ſword.—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: This is no Iriſhman!—what the devil is become of your brogue?—who are you?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A gentleman!—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
A gentleman! ha, ha, ha, this is good!—a gentleman in a livery!—but which are you?
a gentleman in waiting, or a gentleman of the road?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Ah, ah! I now ſee how I came by the new ſuit, ſmuggled from Paris.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: The ſervant is mad, and Sir Buzzard has caught the contagion.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I have it here. (Striking his head.)

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: What have you there?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nothing that I know of, upon my honor.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Nothing in your maſter's head! How dare you joke with your betters, young man?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I ſhall be the laughing-ſtock of fools and jeſt of the malignant.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Oh, dear, dear, ſure there is no harm done! It is all my fault,—Miſs Conſtance is ready to break her heart;—you muſt know, Sir, I was the only perſon in the houſe who knew this gentleman, he is her lover, and he wheedled me, and wheedled me, till I conſented to bring him into the houſe, and ſo I ſhut him into my lady's cloſet.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The girl tells the truth.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: He is a gentleman, and you ſhut him up in your lady's cloſet. (To Sir Buzzard.) Now, I ſee what you conceive in your head.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: And ſo, Sir, my lady coming in, the gentlemen was oblig'd to lie cloſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: And he wheedled you, and wheedled you,—"And he lay cloſe,—Eh"—and he never ſaw your lady?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Never ſaw her, as I hope to be ſaved!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You hear the girl ſwear.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: O, it's plain there was nothing between them.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
"Nothing between them indeed, Sir, that is the naked truth."
Exit Grace.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Then give me leave, Sir, to enquire who you are? and what are your pretenſions to viſit my niece?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: As to my pretenſions, Sir, nothing can be better founded,—I love the lady,—but what is ſtill more material, the lady has long ſince confeſs'd that ſhe loves me.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Candid and open.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: And your name is De Courcy?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To that name I was born, but an old good natured uncle taking it into his head to viſit elizium—in obedience to his will, and in gratitude for ſixteen hundred pounds a year, I now bear the name and arms of Welford.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: You ſeem an honeſt fellow, worthy the love of Conſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: What is his honeſty to me? I am to inform you, Sir, the father of Conſtance is dead; I am her natural guardian, and you ſhall never have my conſent to marry her.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: May I never obtain her conſent, if ever I aſk yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: She has not a ſhilling fortune.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am glad of it, I have ſufficient fortune for both,—I will ſettle a fortune on her.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: A fellow of noble generoſity!—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: There is a gentleman, I am determined ſhe ſhall marry.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
Mark me,—let that gentleman be whom he may, if he preſumes to ſpeak to her, write to her,—or even thinks of her as a wife, I ſhall
make him ſuch an example—but this is loſing time,—farewell, I muſt wait on Conſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: (Oppoſing him.) You ſhall not go an inch into my houſe,—that is your way out.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I will go into any man's houſe, Sir, where ſhe is,—debar me acceſs to my love!—Were you the Grand Signor, and detain'd her, I would force into the inmoſt receſſes of your ſeraglio, put you to death in the midſt of your Janiſſaries, and carry her off in triumph.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I do not often ſwear, it is not my way, but damn me if I would not aſſiſt you.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Nay, then we muſt try your courage, (lays his hand upon his ſword) —O, for an eſtringent to brace my nerves.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Excuſe me from running you through the body while you wear my cloaths; that coat is in excellent taſte, and I cannot think of running it through the body.—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: A ſoldier, and a wit!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
Ord.
sp.p: What, going to ſight a duel!—Oh, for ſhame!—duelling is a mode of ſatisfaction unworthy gentlemen, practis'd now by every vulgar fellow;—people of faſhion ſhould explode it.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: (Trembling.) You know I pay great reſpect to your opinion,—and if,—but he ſhall not go into my houſe.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Conſider what an improper place for quarreling.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p:
You are right, Sir, this is too cold a ſituation for ſtripping;—
(takes up the cloaths
and hands them to Ordeal.) now for Conſtance, love, and happineſs.
Exit Welford, running.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Bravo, my boy!—bravo!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Sure ſome malign devil has determin'd to make me ridiculous!—let me after him. (Ordeal holds him.)

div.stage: Enter Lady FLIPPANT, MUSLIN, and GRACE.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Are you mad, Sir Buzzard?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Stark mad!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Nearly ſtark naked mad.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: The cloaths,—the ſmuggled cloaths you provided for me.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
Away! you old—get home;—perhaps your Scotch tutor may prepare Pure Nature for the grand tour, and provide you more company than you expect.—Why did I marry?—why plunge into a mortal diſeaſe, for which there is no remedy but poiſon,—no relief but death?
Exit Sir Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Can I ſee Conſtance?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: She is lock'd up in her own apartment to avoid her lover.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: To avoid him!—He is a noble fellow, and ſhe muſt have him;—I will in to Sir Buzzard, and argue this caſe:—He preſumes to controul this young lady, his niece, by parental authority; but I will convince him, the principle of that authority is to make our children or wards happy,—not miſerable.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Sir Buzzard is in a horrid rage.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p:
I muſt contrive to appeaſe him. Conſtance I ſuppoſe has her ſuſpicions;—an
amicable girl—I really love her, pity her ſituation, and am determined never to ſee Welford again, but for the purpoſe of facilitating a marriage between them.—I muſt alſo effectuate a breach between my ſiſter and this puſilanimous colonel.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: That may be eaſily accompliſhed—the widow has no ſmall ſhare of vanity.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: True!—

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: We muſt perſuade her ſhe was the object of Mr. Welford's admiration.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I will ſwear he brib'd me to introduce him to her.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: And I will contrive to get her and the gentleman together at my houſe, and your ladyſhip ſhall ſend the Colonel to ſurpirze them, which will produce an irreconcileable quarrel.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Here comes the widow—do you lay the train.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: De Courcy is gone, after a very loud altercation with Cheaterly, which terminated in mutual vows of vengeance; he charges Cheaterly with having impoſed on him at play.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: There is nothing ſcandalous in that—play has become a ſcience, faſhionable in practice, and like other faux pas, 'tis only blameable in diſcovery. Pray how has Conſtance behaved?

sp.speaker: Wdi.
sp.p: Remains locked up in her own room▪ and perſeveres in denying an interview to her lover:—this De Courcy is in my opinion a charming fellow.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: But I muſt know for what purpoſe he was brought into my cloſet.—I am certain Conſtance was not the object; ſo ſpeak, Grace.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Well, my lady, the truth is, the gentleman came after the widow.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I thought ſo,—this duplicity, ſiſter, hurts me.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Dear, my lady, it is all my fault,—the gentleman ſaw Mrs. Volatile at the play with your ladyſhip, and ſent for me in the morning—and,—but am I ſure of pardon if I tell?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Yes, if you tell nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Well, my lady, the poor young gentleman to be fureſwore bitterly he was ſmitten;—by all the Gods, ſays he, ſhe is one of the moſt beautifuleſt,—moſt youngeſt, and moſt eleganteſt creatures my eyes ever beheld!—but I, telling him as how ſhe was poſitively engaged to colonel Staff,—then he began to curſe.—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why preſume to tell him ſo?—Who gave you knowledge of my engagements?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
Grace.
sp.p: Do'nt be angry, madam,—I told him, madam—thinking no harm, and ſo he curs'd, and call'd on Heaven, and poor gentleman ſigh'd ſo, that I took pity on him, and by his perſuaſions and promiſes brought him into the cloſet, where he was to have been concealed,—Yes, ma'am—'till I could have contriv'd to have brought you into the room, which I ſhould have done, but that my lady firſt came, and then Sir Buzzard, who made up the noiſe that diſturb'd the houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You are an impudent girl, go wait in my dreſſing-room 'till my coming.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
Yes, my lady,—but oh, ſure, you do'nt intend to diſcharge me,—what could I do
when ſo pretty a gentleman knelt to me, and cried to me for aſſiſtance—and ſqueez'd my hand, and forc'd a purſe into my boſom—Oh! oh! (crying, apart to the widow) —you will ſpeak to my lady.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I will, Grace! (apart) there (gives money) —let me ſee you preſently.
A pretty ſcheme this!—your maid, Lady Flippant, has uſed me well—did I ever make any poſitive engagements with the Colonel?

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: I hope not, but really you take ſuch pains to torment each other, I was apprehenſive you were privately married.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Heav'n forbid!—I have been prudently conſidering the Colonel's ſituation ſome time paſt—his eſtate I underſtand has been long languiſhing in a decline, and his creditors no doubt are in expectation of mine.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: Then to beſtow it on Welford—think of the pleaſure of ſweet five and twenty ſmiling upon you from morning 'till night.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: And from night to morning—think of that, madam.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: Then our triumph over a girl of ſuch beauty as Conſtance—the buz of the polite world, and their impertinent ill-nature.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Certainly there are inducements.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p:
Inducements! you will have the exquiſite ſatisfaction of being lampoon'd, epigramm'd, and paragraph'd—or perhaps be etch'd in aqua fortis, and ſtuck up in the print ſhops. Then to have the tribe of antiquated maidens, diſguſted wives, and diſappointed widows railing at your prudence, yet envying
your ſituation—"Lord bleſs us!"—ejaculates Lady Toothleſs, "I wonder at her indiſcretion, to marry a man ſo young. The Colonel would have been much more ſuitable."—Then ſhe takes five years from your lover's age, and adds to your's—"That's he!—that's he!"—exclaims Miſs Squintum, as ſhe ogles from a ſide box, with one eye worn out in ſearching for defects in beauty, and the other on the decline—"That's he,—but I cannot perceive what ſhe ſaw in the fellow; he is as plain as herſelf—and I wonder how women can follow fellows."—The blooming youth hands you to your ſeat—the whole circle ſtare at you—a general whiſper's bre • th'd round—you gaze in return with perfect compoſure—ſalute your acquaintance—adjuſt your tucker, giggle behind your fan, aſſume a perfect indifference, whiſper your handſome huſband to mortify them, and laugh out to ſhew your inward ſatisfaction and ineffable contempt.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But how is all this to be brought about?

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Call at my houſe within an hour, and if I do not ſettle it, diſcard me from your confidence.—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: She ſhall be punctual—come, ſiſter, I ſee you were unacquainted with your lover's paſſion,—but you muſt acknowledge I had ſufficient cauſe for ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Yet you muſt allow there was no deceit on my part.
Exit Widow.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: You have play'd your part admirably.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Yes, Muſlin, all good actreſſes are not upon the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: You are no longer a Scotchman I zee—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Yes, Nicholas, I have only laid aſide the tone and accent, but am ſtill a Scotchman; I have no reaſon to be aſhamed of my country, and I truſt my country will never have reaſon to be aſhamed of me.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why zee maſter, I could never zee any difference between your Engliſh and Scotch; though to be zure I could hear it in their ſpeaking, and that is the only difference I think ſhould ever be between them; but take a fool's advice now,—make the beſt uſe of your time.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: What employs your thoughts, my love?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: In truth, love itſelf; if the pleaſing deſcription you have given me be true, and I have no reaſon to doubt your veracity, to live with thoſe we love muſt be the extent of human happineſs;—but then, Mr. Ordeal has told me that your ſex often requite the moſt ſincere paſſion with cold indifference.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: The charge is too true; but my affection can only ceaſe with life.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
I owe every thing to Mr. Ordeal's goodneſs, and the very arguments you urged to gain my love, perſuade me againſt being ungrateful!—obedience is the only return I can make his kindneſs, and how can I diſobey him, when my heart informs me that ingratitude is
one of thoſe heinous ſins at which Heaven is moſt offended?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: It is true, no quality of the ſoul is more lovely than gratitude;—but Mr. Ordeal is not actuated by paſſion,—he offers you his hand from motives of generoſity, not love,—all you owe him is friendſhip, which an union with me could not diminiſh.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You can perſuade me to any thing;—you ſwear you love me,—I believe you,—and if the pleaſure I take in ſeeing you, and hearing you, and the pain I feel when you leave me, be love, I love you above all things.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Have you ſettled every thing?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Good Nicholas, do not interrupt her.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Who, I, a ſpoil-ſport! mum!—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Would not my conſenting to marry you be injuſtice to my benefactor?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: The value I ſet upon your love is ſuch, I would not accept it, but as the voluntary gift of your ſoul!—I will obtain Mr. Ordeal's conſent.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Then I am for ever yours. (He kiſſes her hand.)

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: (aſide) —What do I ſee!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But when will you obtain his conſent?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: O, we are undone.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
(to Douglas) Is this the way you repay my confidence? and you, (to Clara) innocent
miſs, is this a grateful return for years of kindneſs?—But (to Nicholas) what ſhall I ſay to you, raſcal!—you, whom I thought watchful as a lynx, have ſlumber'd like another Argus—were your eyes piped into a nap by this Mercury, or was your mouth ſtopped by a ſop, Mr. Cerberus?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes, I loves a ſop;—but I will be called no names—zee maſter,—our bargain is this, a month's warning, or a month's wages; zo, pay me, and I'll go, but remember it was not I brought maiſter M'Claſſic into the houſe.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Your reſentment, Sir, muſt fall ſolely upon me—I only have deceiv'd you,—a word in private,— (takes Ordeal aſide) could human nature repel the influence of ſuch beauty?— (points to Clara) had I been leſs honourable, or Clara leſs virtuous, I might now perhaps be impoſing upon your credulity a ſeduced maid, with a vitiated mind: I am young,—Clara is pure nature,—the experiment I have made was dangerous.—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: But you were only to have made the experiment to try how far her inclinations coincided with mine.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Conſider, ſhe was an orange tree.—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: You were to have been the inſtrument for promoting my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: She poſſeſs'd the verdure of the ſpring—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Hear me!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: The bloſſom of the ſummer—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Hear me!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: The ripe fruit of autumn.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
And you would conſider me the falling leaf in winter—hear me, Sir!— (loud) Hav •
you not been urging the temptations of pleaſure to ſeduce her into your own deſigns?—have you not alienated her affections from me?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Sir, I came into your houſe for the very purpoſe of gaining her love.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: A ſoldier—my name Douglas,—my fortune a competency,—my country Scotland—the ſame perſon who aſſiſted you when attack'd by ruffians on Marlborough Downs.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: The kind gentleman in whoſe arms I fainted!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: From the firſt inſtant I ſaw her, my ſoul caught the inſpiration of virtuous love.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: You are unfaſhionable, Sir,—from the diſſipated converſation of the young fellows of the times, one would imagine there was neither honeſty in man, nor chaſtity in woman;—but your conduct contradicts their aſperſions.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: It is too true, the arts of ſeduction are ſo ſedulouſly ſtudied, that honeſt love appears in danger of being extirpated.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: There are many, many melancholy examples;—but be aſſured, young man, though ſenſual pleaſures ariſe from ſeducing innocence, it is plucking bloſſoms from a ſweet-briar, which will rankle in the fleſh.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Your obſervation, Sir, is juſt,—though it does not apply to me.—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: "My cenſure does not fall ſolely on youth,—no, the gardens of beauty and innocence are alſo deſpoil'd by old debilitated wretches, who cannot cultivate the ſoil, but lay waſte its beauties."

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Do you forgive me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I blame you not, I am your debtor for many inſtances of duty and affection;—look on her, Douglas;—yet her beauty is the leaſt of her excellence,—but as it is a principal part of benevolence to aſſiſt another moſt when there is moſt need of aſſiſtance,—and that you need not owe too much to the generoſity of your huſband,—as you cannot be my wife, I adopt you for my child—love inſpires its votaries with ſentiment, and I acknowledge the benign influence. (Joins their hands.)

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: You weep, my lovely Clara!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: And ſo do you,—and ſo do I,—I ſee you are all joy,—but, my children, the tranſports of a virtuous paſſion are the leaſt parts of its happineſs,—we will this inſtant to Sir Buzzard Savage's,—a young lady, his niece, calls for my protection.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: You mean Conſtance Heartfree! young De Courcy, of York, my particular friend, is, I believe, betrothed to her.—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: You are right;—take your bride by the hand;—the women will laugh at me for loſing her, but I am above the laugh of the world, and I will laugh at the world in my turn,—that is my way.— Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I. Lady Flippant's Dreſſing Room.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: THE ſtorm bends this way, and here will I meet it. (Sits down, and takes a book.)

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: (Puſhing Grace before him) you ſhall inſtantly march out of my houſe. (Puſhes her.)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: My lady ſcorns your ſuſpicions.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Stop your gabble, you diminitive pandar in petticoats!—It is clear that Conſtance was ignorant of Welford's arrival in England!—it is apparent he did not come to my houſe after her.—What, is your noble blood at a loſs for an excuſe?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Who has inſtilled jealouſy into that head of yours, barren of every thing but what is monſtrous! (Reads.)

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: It is your Ladyſhip has made my head monſtrous.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sure the devil inſtigates ſome women!—the widow—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Do not throw the blame on the poor devil—it is nature inſtigates them, and ſhe is to the full as ſubtle and certain in her operations.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
I juſt now ſpoke to her as ſhe ſtept out of a chair into Mrs. Muſlin's, and in return was
ſhot through the heart with a look of ill-nature and contempt—if I was not the cooleſt fellow in the ſervice, I'd run mad,—aye,—mad, mad—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You would have cauſe to run mad, if you knew ſhe is now at Mrs. Muſlin's, enjoying a tete-a-tete with Welford.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I am ready to take my oath of it! (to Sir Buzzard) the truth is, I told a great lie to your honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
O, confound me, but I believe you now.
Exit Grace.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The widow gone to Welford, on an aſſignation—ha! ha! ha! I will after her this inſtant, and cut his throat!—No, I will not ſtir—I am pleas'd—perfectly pleas'd!—I will diſcharge ſuch a volley about his ears;—gone to viſit Welford!—but why ſhould I be vex'd?—I will follow her, ſpring a mine, and blow them up together—Burſt on her like a hand-granade.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Ridiculous—you are all gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ungrateful woman!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Deceitful ſex!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Surprize her and her lover!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I will break with her—I mean I will purſue her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Well, you ſee it was your ſiſter, not your wife, Welford came to viſit; are you ready to make an apology for your vulgar ſuſpicions?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
An apology to you! O, impudence! have you not been the ruſt of my health, have you not fretted me down to a mere ſkeleton?
make you an apology!—give me my waſted fleſh.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I ſhall for London in the morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: If you dare!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Will ſhew out at every place of public entertainment.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: At your peril.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: At your coſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: The law gives me authority to confine you, and I will exerciſe it—I am your huſband.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I am heartily ſorry for it! will have public breakfaſts, public dinners, and public nights.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You ſhall have bread and water, in a narrow room.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: A box at the Opera, and ſubſcribe to all the Concerts.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You devil!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Will purchaſe a new vis-a-vis—a town chariot and phaeton.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You—you have a deſign upon my life.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p:
Heav'ns! how ardently I pant to be elevated in the phaeton, to take the circuit of Hyde Park, rolling in a cloud of duſt, four horſes, two outriders, whip in hand, flowing manes, hunters tails, ſweep down Piccadilly, turn into St. James's-ſtreet,—up fly the clubhouſe windows, out pop the powdered heads of the bucks and beauxs of faſhion—ſome nod, ſome ſmile, ſome kiſs hands,—all praiſe—ſhe is a goddeſs, exclaims one,—a venus, ejaculates another,—an angel, ſighs a third. I cut on, flaſh
down Pall Mall ſwift as lightning, rattle furiouſly through Charing-Croſs, overturn Lady Dapper's whim and cats at Northumberland Houſe, loſe a wheel in the Strand, leap from my ſeat as the carriage falls, and am received in the arms of ſome handſome fellow whom love has directed to my aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: She is mad! ſhe is mad! outrageous mad!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: He carries me into a houſe, fainting—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Stop there; I will be divorc'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Then I will have a ſeparate maintenance.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Not a ſhilling.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You cannot deprive me of my ſettlement.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
Ay, there is the grievance! O, confound all jointures and ſettlements, thoſe encourage your levities, and ſtimulate you all to tranſgreſs.
Exit Sir Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Sits.) My poor ſpirits are exhauſted! Heigh ho! I am tired of this diſſipated life.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I wait upon your ladyſhip, to return grateful thanks for the many favours you have conferred upon me, and to take my leave, as I am determined to quit this houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: What! without your uncle's conſent?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I cannot think his conſent neceſſary, while he and your ladyſhip aſſent to the perſecution I experienced from a man I deſpiſe.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Riſing) And pray where do you intend to go?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I have found a protector—Mr. Ordeal, the friend of my unfortunate father. Lady Flippant, it hurts my heart to part you upon thoſe terms. (Weeps and walks as going.)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: In tears, Conſtance! (Conſtance returns) Why ſo diſtreſs'd?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: My heart is too full.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Be ſeated; (they ſit) you love this Mr. Welford ſincerely—but he is! (aſide) what is it to me what he is! (Riſes)

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: To me he is every thing—and it is my hope!— (riſes) —but why ſhould I hope?—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Conſtance—I really love you—our manners have divided us; but be aſſured, my dear girl, though I run the circle of faſhionable life, my mind is not devoid of ſenſibility—our education has been different.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: It was my happineſs to receive inſtruction from a pious and tender mother, who early taught me the precepts of virtue, and impreſſed upon my heart, that a pure reputation with humble poverty, was preferable to a ſuſpicious character, though blazoned with all the pomp and ornaments of elevated life—but ſhe is no more.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Riſes) Alas, Conſtance! it was my misfortune to be educated in all the giddy foibles and levities of the times.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: (Riſes) But I have obſerved a diſpoſition in your ladyſhip ſuſceptible of the tendereſt offices of friendſhip,—and where there is feeling—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p:
There is hope of reformation—you would have ſaid ſo—indeed, Conſtance,
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
there are ſentiments here, which often upbraid me; but ſure nothing has tranſpir'd, injurious to my honour.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: The world is cenſorious, madam, and thoſe whoſe converſation is the moſt entertaining are often the moſt dangerous; to ſimplicity they impute cunning, and give a criminal conſtruction to the moſt innocent actions.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I am all joy, Lady Flippant! Conſtance, this is Clara, hereafter I truſt you will be inſeparable friends.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I ſhall endeavour to merit the lady's friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: They may boaſt of Queen Emma walking over burning ploughſhares, but here is a girl has done more, ſhe has lived in a faſhionable family without cenſure. (Takes Conſtance by the hand.)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: But, Mr. Ordeal, what is the cauſe of your joy?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: It muſt be diſclos'd—Pure Nature has beſtowed her hand and heart on the Scotch lad, who turns out to be Captain Douglas, Welford's intimate friend.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Sir, I know the gentleman, and he bears a high character.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Conſtance, take this young lady to the drawing-room, ſend Grace to me, and order your maid over to Welford's, to let him know you will be there preſently. I have a ſerious reaſon for my requeſt, and will not be denied.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
I obey.
Exeunt Conſtance and Clara.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: The poor girl's ſituation is truly pitiable—it was our ſubject when you came in—the tears are not yet out of my eyes.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Never bluſh for weeping; tears are the certain ſymptoms of a noble ſoul.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Do you know that I have ſerious thoughts of throwing aſide all faſhionable levities?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I know it is almoſt time; I believe your inclinations are virtuous, and your irregularities I do not impute to nature;—no, my lady, nature has endowed you with amiable qualities, among which, I think generoſity is prevalent—like moſt of your ſex, you have taken up levity through whim, and maintain it through habit, though perhaps your ſoul ſtruggles to be delivered from the trammels;—break them, then, and you will do more than Caeſar;—he conquered countries,—but the greateſt glory human nature can acquire is to conquer ourſelves;—I have good news for Conſtance,—her father is living.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Heav'ns!—are you ſerious?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I have had letters from London, and he returns by the next ſhips from India;—nay more,—he has remitted thirty thouſand pounds to her ſole uſe, with directions to prepare a houſe for his reception.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: O, I am overjoy'd—why has ſhe never heard from him before?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: He was ſent upon an embaſſy to the interior parts of the country, and his letters were intercepted and deſtroyed.—But ſeriouſly, has your ladyſhip known nothing of this before?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: There is roguery on foot,—an expreſs was ſent to your ſeat at York, which not meeting the lady there was forwarded to this city, and delivered at this houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
Ord.
sp.p: I hope ſo!—but I believe nothing without proof—that is my way—where there is levity the world will ſuſpect, and when the world has once cauſe to ſuſpect a woman, her character becomes as much the ſport of its malice, as if there was a certainty of her having abandoned it.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I am penitent! but do you really forgive my lecture to Pure Nature?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Yes, and am convinc'd you are no falſe prophet; for, as you foretold, Clara preferred the ſummer dimples of youth to the winter wrinkles of age,—I ſpeak my mind, that is my way.

div.head: SCENE II. Mrs. Muſlin's.
div.stage: The WIDOW, Mrs. MUSLIN, and WELFORD, diſcovered at Tea.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
Your opinion, madam, is juſt! vivacity is an attribute to woman,—gravity natural
to man:—and probably the ſexes were thus contraſted, that the ſaturnine diſpoſition of the male might be relieved by the ſprightlineſs of the female,—your ſmiles alleviate our pains, your approbation rewards our dangers.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And our converſation illuſtrates my opinion—you are grave,—I, perhaps, too volatile.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: The poor gentleman ſeems as if ſomething preyed upon his mind;—let me recommend matrimony,—it is the only cure for melancholy.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And often a ſpecific for all complaints.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Well,—buſineſs muſt be minded (going.)

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: (Riſes.) Muſt ſee you to the door.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: (Aſide.) A great fortune,—may I truſt her with you?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
May I truſt myſelf with her? (aſide.)
Exit Mrs. Muſlin. A good, merry, convenient, civil old woman:—ſhe recommends matrimony— (ſits.) Pray, madam, what kind of lover would you prefer?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I muſt tell you the lover I would not prefer. I would not prefer a coxcomb,—a fluttering ſummer inſect,—a talkative creature, full of inſipid geſture, laughter, and noiſe, who pays more attention to his hair than to his intellects,—who poſſeſſes neither ſentiment for friendſhip, nor ſenſibility for love—but is curſt with a ſoul devoid of manlineſs, and bent on the gratification of its own puny affections.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: An excellent picture, yet the ſpecies of animal you deſcribe are favorites.—The ladies are grown ſo enamoured of delicate limbs, and effeminate faces, one would imagine they wiſhed to have their lovers women in every thing.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Dear Sir, there is a woman below enquiring for you—ſhe inſiſts upon coming up, and has ſuch a tongue!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I would not be ſeen for the world.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p:
She would ſurely blaſt the reputation of my houſe.—Sir, you muſt go down to her.—O my poor character!
Exit Mrs. Muſlin.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Any thing to ſave the reputation of your houſe. (Going.)

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Madam, madam, the ſlut is upon the ſtairs.—Step into this cloſet till the impudent creature is gone.— (Puts the widow in the cloſet) You do not know, Sir, you have been ſitting with Mrs. Volatile, ſiſter to Sir Buzzard Savage.

sp.speaker: Honor.
sp.p: (Within) Mr. Welford.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I know that voice.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: It is the clack of Mrs. Honor, waiting maid to Miſs Conſtance.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Then keep her out for Heaven's ſake.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: (Within) I will have admittance.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p:
Coming, Mrs. Honor.—O the audacious wretch—I ſee, Sir, you are a man of gallantry, but, pray, diſpatch the creature as faſt as poſſible.
Exit. Muſ.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: (Within) Madam I inſiſt upon going in firſt.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (Within) No me'm—you will pardon me.

div.stage: Enter GRACE and HONOR puſhing in together.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What, two!—ladies, your moſt obedient.— (bows—they curtſey)

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: You have no buſineſs here, me'm,—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: My buſineſs, me'm, is no buſineſs of your's—or if it was your buſineſs, me'm, yet it is not the buſineſs of the likes of you to look down upon the likes of me, me'm.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: The likes of you I look down upon with ſcorn.—It is not for the likes of you, to look up to the likes of me, me'm.—I ſerves a lady of vartue.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Vartue! Your inſinuation is low, me'm, high as you carry your head.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Grace, ſtand on my right hand—Honor, take your place on my left—How happy would it be for England, were all her great men in my ſituation—Grace ſupporting one ſide, Honor ſupporting the other.—Now, ladies, to the cauſe of your viſit.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: My lady underſtanding that her ſiſter was here— together.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: My Lady ſent me to let you know— together.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: One at a time.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Sir, you muſt know— together.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: My lady ſent— together.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Here is a guinea for her who ſpeaks ſecond—What; dumb!—but money ſeals as well as unſeals the mouths of great ſpeakers.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Me'm, I ſhall certainly ſpeak firſt—Sir, you muſt know—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Speak firſt, me'm! I ſerve a lady of quality.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Order in the houſe—let me ſettle this point of precedence—I believe it is regular that Grace ſhould take the lead of Honor, ſo Mrs. Grace begin.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Thank you for preferring ſhe.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Now Grace, what is your baſineſs with me?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: La, Sir, I have no buſineſs with you—I want to ſpeak with Mrs. Volatile.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Child, ſhe is not here.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Not here—but I believe ſhe is there

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: By this guinea ſhe is not. (gives money.)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
By this guinea I will ſwear it—mum—but my lady wants to ſee her directly—Mrs. Honor, your very obedient—an audacious huſſey!— (aſide.)
Exit Grace.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Me'm, your moſt humble— (aſide.) Lord, Sir, I found it as difficult to get at you, as if you had been a great Turk.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Mrs. Muſlin did not know you perhaps.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Not know me! ſhe knew me to be vartuous, though as the ſaying is, "tell me your company and I will tell you what you are"—and I, and my miſtreſs live in a family where there is not much vartue practiſed—but I am ſilent—ſervants ſhould neither have eyes, nor ears, nor tongues, therefore I am always blind, deaf and dumb, let me hear or ſee what I may.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lower your voice, you may be overheard.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Then there is Sir Buzzard's ſiſter, the widow, though her huſband is not dead ſix months, is friſky and briſk—gadding about, and running mad for another—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Speak low, a gentleman lies ill in the next room.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
As to Sir Buzzard, they have put their
fingers into his eyes ſo often, he is blind as a beetle. I muſt make you laugh about the widow—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I cannot permit you to ſtay any longer from your Lady. Here's for your good report

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Dear Sir, you diſtreſs me—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
Farewell— (puſhing her out.)
Exit Honor. Heav'n be prais'd! I have got rid of you!—Now to relieve my widow, who I ſuppoſe is mortified into humility, or burſting with rage.

Madam, I feel for your ſituation, and did every thing in my power to ſtop the impetuous flow of the woman's tongue—but be not affected at what ſhe ſaid—"Cenſure and calumny are taxes paid by the moſt elevated characters, nor is it poſſible to make defence againſt the impoſt, but by obſcurity."

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It is beneath me, Sir, to defend my character againſt the aſperſions of ſo mean a wretch—I feel however for the impreſſions her falſhoods may have made on you.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: You ſeem frightened, madam, quite fluſter'd I proteſt—ſure the gentleman attempted no rudeneſs—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That woman has ſlandered me groſly!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Soothe your paſſion, madam, nothing ſo prejudicial to beauty as intemperate warmth—conſider the vulgar ſet up a preſcription, for exerciſing latitude of tongue, that ſhews no reſpect to perſons.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your hand, Mrs. Muſlin—ſome drops—ſome water—I faint—I am overcome—I die! oh! (faints in Welford's arms.)

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Support her, dear Sir, 'till I return—let me run for reſtoratives— (going, returns) open her hands, chafe her temples,—a-lack a day—This is a maſter ſtroke of the widow's!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: This is worſe than the ſtate of Tantalus—human nature cannot hold out—ſhe is really handſome. I will venture to kiſs her however—

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Madam, Sir,—there is Miſs Conſtance and Colonel Staff with her—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What will become of me? (Springing from the couch.)

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: In his private chamber, and juſt ſprung from his arms!—Oh, hell and furies! but I will be cool,—we, Sir, will meet hereafter; this intruſion, madam, is, I ſee, as unſeaſonable as unexpected; I am ſorry to have interrupted you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am unconcerned at your ſuſpicions, Colonel,—you will not be cenſorious, Miſs Conſtance—my buſineſs here was to prevent that imprudent ſtep which you are about to take.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You have ſucceeded, madam (going).

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Will you hear me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I am ſorty, Sir, for the confuſion I have cauſed—having gained my eſteem without difficulty—you have reſign'd it with the ſame eaſe—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (To the Widow) This undeniable proof of your duplicity has reinſtated my ſenſes, and I will run the gauntlet no longer—you feel am calm—quite calm,—but I will have revenge;—you, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Well, Sir!—it is my duty to clear this lady from ſuſpicion, to which her ſituation lays her open, and in which I am innocently involved.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You may have an intereſt in juſtifying yourſelf, Sir, but I requeſt not to be included in your defence; I am going.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I give up the purſuit—Madam, if my acts and deeds—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your acts and deeds! Yes, I have heard of your acts and deeds from yourſelf, Colonel—but, be aſſured, a man without ſpirit ſhall never controul the acts and deeds of my fortune.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A true Parthian,—ſhe ſhot as ſhe ſlew.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Conſtance, will you attend to me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
No, Sir,—you need not take the trouble
of ſpeaking to me now, or of enquiring for me hereafter.
Exit. Conſtance.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Was ever man ſo unfortunate!—to have all my wiſhes blaſted in the moment of ripening!—to loſe the object of my love in the inſtant of recovering her—who waits there? to have an intrigue with a wife, a widow, and a maid, in the courſe of one day, and be diſappointed in all—will nobody anſwer? (calling loud.)

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: What is the mater, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Where is the lady?

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: She went out with the Colonel.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I ſpeak of the young lady.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: She left the houſe in a chair,—but I cannot tell where ſhe went.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
I will this inſtant to Sir Buzzard's!—I will follow her over the world;—what an unfortunate fellow!—
Exit. Welford.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Parade. Enter CHEATERLY, followed by a ſervant.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: What anſwer has Doctor Spruce ſent?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He ſaid, Sir, he would not write,—but remember your ungenerous treatment, and have revenge!—pardon me, Sir, but theſe were his words.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Would have revenge?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
Yes, Sir, and I ſaw a letter on his table directed to Sir Buzzard Savage;—there was an
attorney with him, and I heard him ſay the penalty is treble the money loſt.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: How much is he arreſted for?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Upwards of ſeventy pounds.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Here is a note for a hundred— (gives a note) fly and get him diſcharged.
A letter to Sir Buzzard!—an attorney with him!—treble the penalty!—this Spruce I fear will turn traitor.
Captain Douglas, your moſt obedient,—how long have you been in Bath? I have not ſeen you for an age.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I believe, Sir, not ſince the York meeting, when my friend De Courcy loſt his money.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: He is too ardent to attempt play,—always off his guard.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: And had the misfortune to play with thoſe who kept a conſtant centinel upon his weakneſs;—he confided in you, and was deceived;—care, and a plain underſtanding, may preſerve a man's property from the plunder of a common robber,—but honeſty has no protection from the frauds of ſuperior cunning.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I won nothing from him;—I loſt—the truth is, the knowing ones took us in.—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: But you ſhared the winnings—

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Will you dare—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I will dare any thing that is honeſt.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Your friend, Sir, has dared to traduce my character, by the imputation you inſinuate. But he and you ſhould know me better, than to ſuppoſe any man could affront me with impunity. (lays his hand on his ſword.)

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I know you have a mind capable of vindicating your conduct, even at the riſque of your own life, and the life of him you have injured—men like you, habituated in deceit, become callous to humanity;—deſtitute of principle,—they are not deterred by the compunctions of conſcience,—but will inſure the profits of their cunning, even at the price of blood.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: My family, Sir—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Is honourable!—ſpeak not of your family—their virtues render your vices the more conſpicuous.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Oh you traitor!—the reverend Mr▪ Spruce has made a full confeſſion.—So I have been your pigeon, but the law ſhall do me juſtice.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: This is your ſcheme, puſillanimous, mean wretch— (to Sir Buzzard) for you, Sir, (to Douglas) we ſhall meet again.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes,—at the next aſſizes;—the fellow's mind is ſowed with hempſeed, and will yet produce a halter.—or if he eſcapes hanging, I ſhall ſee him periſhing in a gaol, under as many wants as are in the Daily Advertiſer;—have you been pigeon'd, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I have,—he has pluck'd ſome quill feathers from me,—he has pinion'd me!—oh the raſcal!—but I ſhall recover my mortgages, and bonds, with treble penalties!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Diſtraction!—ſhe is loſt!—I have been at your houſe, my Lady,—at Mr. Ordeal's—at every inn in the town,—but can get no tidings of her.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: It is ſurpriſing, you, who poſſeſs a heart open and liberal, panting with affection for the whole ſex, ſhould run diſtracted for the loſs of an individual!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: You overlook me, Welford—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Douglas!—my friend!—O, Douglas, I have loſt my Conſtance!—I—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: No truant, I have been your advocate and regained her for you—on condition of repentance—.

div.stage: Enter CONSTANCE and CLARA followed by ORDEAL.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My life!— (they embrace.)

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Repentance!—let him marry, and he will live and die in a ſtate of repentance.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: What!—marry me, an orphan without a ſhilling?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Talk not of wealth,—were the riches of the world in your poſſeſſion, by Heaven they would not add a grain to the eſtimation of your worth.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Generous and noble!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: (to Ord.) How, Sir, can I repay your generoſity?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: The ſatisfaction which reſults from aiding virtue in diſtreſs, is the only intereſt a generous mind can wiſh to receive for its ſervices;—becauſe it is the only intereſt ſuch a mind can enjoy.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Return to my houſe;—there you ſhall be acquainted with a matter which nearly concerns your happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Which I never expect to taſte!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Your happineſs is in your own power, commence the practice of virtue, and you will be enamoured of its ſweets,—try the experiment, and never fear ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: What ſay you to that, Sir Buzzard?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I ſay a man can never be too old to mend—I ſay I have been poſitive all my life, and I ſay if you follow the advice of your ancient and ſapient friend, my endeavours to procure domeſtic happineſs ſhall not be wanting—Ordeal, the laugh will be againſt us both.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Laugh at me as long as you pleaſe, but had I married Clara, the laugh would have been ſtill ſtronger againſt me;—the Scot has done right, and the girl has done right,—the mutual inclination of two virtuous ſouls, cannot but render them more virtuous;—the inhabitants of countries united by nature and policy ſhould take every opportunity of ſtrengthening the connexion;—I ſee you all think as I do!—and here I hope we ſhall alſo meet approbation.

sp.l: OUR growing Levities too clearly ſhow,
That all our troubles from refinement flow.
Two ages ſince we valu'd plain attire,
Blue-apron'd was the Dame, ſtraight-hair'd the Squire;
They call'd not houſhold bus'neſs vulgar cares,
Nor deem'd it ungenteel to ſay their pray'rs:
But arts improv'd, new Levities aroſe,
And Ladies chang'd the faſhion of their clothes;
Hoop'd petticoats in ev'ry town were ſeen:
The ſnug rotunda pleas'd the virgin Queen,
And beef for breakfaſt ſerv'd her Lady-train;
No wonder that her ſailors baffled Spain.
Yet ſtill we've chiefs with love of glory fir'd;
But ſo had Rome when liberty expired;
"We've ſtateſmen too, who burn with patriots flame,
"But ſo had Greece, when Greece had loſt her fame."
"We've admirals who plow the briny deep,
"Through azure ſkies and rolling clouds they ſweep,
"Invade the Planets in an Air Balloon,
"And fright from her propriety the Moon"—
Beſs was a man, when danger call'd her pow'rs,
She was a woman in her private hours—
Few Levities, few luxuries ſhe knew;
No cherries then in February grew:
May-dukes in April on the bough hung green,
And girls wore hanging-ſleeves till full eighteen.
Few mothers teach their daughters grace or ſenſe▪
But tell them taſte in dreſs is excellence:
Bid them the Levities of rank aſſume,
And flaunt with ſpreading bow, or nodding plume;
Strut in a riding-dreſs, to ſhew their ſhapes;
Or ſtalk in boots, and coats with tripple capes.
Affecting eaſe, but impudently free,
The matron leans upon her ciciſbee;
While cara ſpoſa ſnugly keeps his wench,
Defies his duns, and revels in the Bench.
"Why, this is vice, not folly?" I agree;
But ſtill this vice proceeds from Levity.
Some ſouls there are which moral ſenſe ſublimes,
A few bleſt ſpirits in the worſt of times;
One in whom birth and piety are join'd;
Of native worth, and truly royal mind;
Who with benignant hand her bleſſings pours;
Who knows no Levities, but feels for yours.
